characters: CLOSE ON THE DEAD GIRL'S FACE
IN THE MIRROR, (DISTORTED BY THE ANGLE)
AT THE LIP OF THE OUBLIETTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman's face BACKS INTO SHOT, her head resting against  grimy wallpaper. She is tense, sweaty, wide-eyed with  concentration. This is CLARICE STARLING, mid-20's, trim,  very pretty. She wears Kevlar body armor over a navy  windbreaker, khaki pants. Her thick hair is piled under a navy baseball cap. A revolver, clutched in her right hand hovers by her ear. She raises a speedloader, in her left  hand, locks it into her cylinder, twists and reloads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A guest room door, with a small, wired pack attached to i knob. Suddenly, wish a sharp CRACK!, the knob explodes, a the door bursts open.

dialogues.speaker: WITH CLARICE
dialogues.text: as she runs around a corner, through a cloud of smoke. Sh shoulders aside the shattered door and rushes inside, gun the ready in both hands...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARICE'S POV - MOVING - as she first sees, sitting on th edge of a bed - a FEMALE HOSTAGE. Black, late 20's, gagge hands behind her back. Then, SWIVELLING... she sees a sta MALE SUSPECT, white, mid-20's, standing by a window with rifle in his hands. He is turning towards her... Clarice drops into a combat crouch, gun extended, and sho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freeze! FBI!

dialogues.speaker: SLOW MOTION
dialogues.text: all natural SOUND suspended - as the Suspect faces her wi a strange, pleading expression. The rifle is rising in hi hands, but oddly enough, it is held across his chest, not pointing. Then another puzzling detail registers...

dialogues.speaker: THE SUSPECT'S HANDS
dialogues.text: are taped to his gun, away from the trigger; he couldn't it even if he tried. Suddenly we hear a metallic CLICK, w registers with unnatural amplification, as - Clarice reac drops to the floor, rolling sideways, and -

dialogues.speaker: THE "HOSTAGE"
dialogues.text: pulls a revolver out from behind her back, still in SLOW  MOTION, raising it in her untied hands. She fires repeate flames leaping from the muzzle; the SOUND is an echoing r in these close quarters, but - Clarice has come up on one knee, beside an armchair, and already firing back herself, two quick SHOTS, which send

dialogues.speaker: THE "HOSTAGE"
dialogues.text: pitching over the bed, backwards, to shudder and lie stil in a haze of gunsmoke. Clarice rushes to her, clamping on knee down on her gun hand, still keeping her covered in c of movement. HOLD for a few beats... then we hear the shr blast of a WHISTLE from somewhere, off screen, as normal  ACTION and SOUND are restored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, people, good exercise...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice relaxes, lowering her gun. The lights brighten.

dialogues.speaker: PULLING BACK
dialogues.text: we see that we're in some sort of auditorium, with the "h room" and its "corridor" built as a training set. JOHN BR walks onto this set, thumbing a stopwatch. Mid-40's, ex- Marine. His T-shirt's lettering says "Firearms Instructor FBI Academy."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Starling's reaction time was  excellent. Let's break. Critique in  five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A class of about forty young FBI trainees, of both sexes, begins to rise from their seats, mingling and chatting.  Clarice nods amiably to the "Suspect", then gives her  "Hostage" a hand up. It's ARDELIA MAPP, her roommate. Her broad, clever face breaks into a big smile, as they both  remove ear plugs. Clarice's voice has just a soft trace o southern accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn, Clarice, how'd you make me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating her gun) Never cock. Just squeeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins) I love it when you talk dirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Brigham joins them, Clarice can't resist a star pupil' little smile of pride. He frowns good-naturedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you laughin' at, Junior G- Man? She got off four rounds to your  two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes out a steel-coiled grip flexer, drops it onto he palm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) One hundred reps, each hand, every  day. Now tidy up, the Section Chief  wants to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods a direction, then moves off. Clarice, with her sm finally fading, looks out into the auditorium.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL AGENT JACK CRAWFORD
dialogues.text: sits on the top step of the aisle, looking down at her. H is 53, strongly built. He rises impassively, exits throug the back door. He carries a think manila envelope under o arm. Ardelia who is helping Clarice unbuckle her bullet-proof  vest, follows her worried gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay cool. Just remember to call him  "God."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford is watching a group of trainees on the firing ra as Clarice joins him. He looks tired, haunted. Between ma and student, we sense a subtle, muted tug of sexuality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Starling, Clarice M., good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Crawford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your instructors tell me you're doing  well. Top quarter of the class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope so. They haven't posted  anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A job's come up and I thought about  you. Not really a job, more of - an  interesting errand. Walk me to my  car, Starling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They begin to cross the academy grounds. A group of train jogs by, in matching sweats, following a p.e. coach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're trying to interview all of the  serial killers now in custody, for a  psychobehavioral profile. Could be a  big help in unsolved cases. Most of  them have been happy to talk to us.  They have a compulsion to boast,  these people... Do you spook easily,  Starling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, the one we want most refuses  to cooperate. I want you to go after  him again today, in the asylum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the subject?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The psychiatrist - Dr. Hannibal  Lecter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice stops walking, goes very still. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cannibal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford doesn't respond, except to study her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well... Okay, right. I'm glad  for the chance, sir, but - why me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're qualified and available. And  frankly, I can't spare a real agent  right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks on again, at a faster clip. She hurried to keep

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't expect him to talk to you,  but I have to be able to say we  tried... Lecter was a brilliant  psychiatrist, and he knows all the  dodges. (hands her the manila  envelope) Dossier on him, copy of our  questionnaire, special ID for you...  If he won't talk, then I want straight  reporting. How's he look, how's his  cell look, what's he writing? The  Director himself will see your report,  over your own signature - if I decide  it's good enough. I want that by  0800 Wednesday, and keep this to  yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're reached his car. His driver stamps on a cigarette climbs in behind the wheel. BURROUGHS, his assistant, say something into a walkie-talkie, then opens the back door. But Crawford pulls her aside, a hand on her shoulder. His intensity is scary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now. I want your full attention,  Starling. Are you listening to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be very careful with Hannibal Lecter.  Dr. Chilton at the asylum will go  over the physical procedures used  with him. Do not deviate from them,  for any reason. You tell him nothing  personal, Starling. Believe me, you  don't want Hannibal Lecter inside  your head... Just do your job, but  never forget what he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit unnerved) And what is that, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, he's a monster. A pure  psychopath...

dialogues.speaker: CRIMINALLY INSANE
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON an ID card held in a male hand. Clarice's photo, official-looking graphics. It calls her a "Federal  Investigator."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so rare to capture one alive.  From a research point of view, Dr.  Lecter is our most prized asset...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. FREDERICK CHILTON looks up from her card. A smarmy li peacock, behind a vast desk; he's conceived an instant,  hopeless letch for Clarice. He smiles, stroking her card  with his beloved gold pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, we get a lot of detectives  here, but I must say, I can't ever  remember one so attractive...

dialogues.speaker: REVEALS CLARICE
dialogues.text: now wearing a more feminine skirt suit. Hair neatly coile elegant shoulder bag, briefcase. He has rudely left her  standing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you be in Baltimore overnight...?  Because this can be quite a fun town,  if you have the right guide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice tries, unsuccessfully, to hide her distaste for h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure it's a great town, Dr.  Chilton, but my instructions are to  talk to Lecter and report back this  afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause, sourly) I see. (beat) Let's make this quick, then. I'm  busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice flinches as a heavy steel gate CLANGS shut behind her, the bolt shooting home. Chilton walks ahead of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lecter carved up nine people - that  we're sure of - and cooked his  favorite bits. We've tried to study  him, of course - but he's much too  sophisticated for the standard tests.  And my, does he hate us! Thinks I'm  his nemesis... Crawford's very clever,  isn't he? Using you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you mean, Dr. Chilton?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pretty young woman, to turn him  on? I don't believe Lecter's ever  seen a woman in eight years. And oh,  are you ever his "taste" - so to  speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I graduated magna from UVA, Doctor.  It's not a charm school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Then you should be able to  remember the rules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A darker, even grimmer area. Heavy grids over the lights. Distant SLAMMINGS and faint, hoarse SHOUTS. They walk bri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not reach through the bars, do  not touch the bars. You pass him  nothing but soft paper - no pens or  pencils. No staples or paperclips in  his paper. Use the sliding food  carrier, no exceptions. Do not accept  anything he attempts to hold out to  you. Do you understand me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to show you why we insist  on such precautions... On the  afternoon of July 8, 1981, he  complained of chest pains and was  taken to the dispensary. His  mouthpiece and restraints were removed  for an EKG. When the nurse bent over  him, he did this to her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands Clarice a small, dog-eared photo. Looking at it, she is stopped in her tracks. This pleases Chilton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctors managed to re-set her  jaw, more or less, and save one of  her eyes. His pulse never got over  eighty-five, even when he ate her  tongue. (pauses, he smiles) I keep him in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns, pushes a button. A steel door BUZZES slowly ope and BARNEY - a big, impassive orderly - awaits them in an anteroom. On its walls: restraints, mouthpieces, Mace,  tranquilizer guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly blocking him) Dr. Chilton - if Lecter feels you're  his enemy - as you've said - then  maybe I'll have more luck by myself.  What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed) You might have suggested that in my  office, and saved me the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then I would've missed the  pleasure of your company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds out the photo. A beat. He grabs it, jaw twitchi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When she's finished, bring her out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns on his heel, goes. Barney smiles reassuringly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Barney. He told you, don't  get near the bars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his hand) Clarice Starling. Yes, he did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Past the others, it's the last  cell. Stay to the middle. I put out  a chair for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sensing her tension, he indicates a nearby security monit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm watching. You'll do fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice nods gratefully. She looks down the long corridor takes a deep breath, walks into it. He watches her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING SHOT - with Clarice, as her footsteps ECHO. High t her right, surveillance cameras. On her left, cells. Some are padded, with narrow observation slits, others are nor barred... Shadowy occupants pacing, MUTTERING... Suddenly dark figure in the next-to-last cell hurtles towards her, his face mashing grotesquely against his bars as he hisse

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I c-can sssmell your cunt!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice flinches momentarily, but then walks on.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LECTER'S CELL
dialogues.text: is coming slowly INTO VIEW... Behind its barred front wal is a second barrier of stout nylon net... Sparse, bolted- down furniture, many softcover books and papers. On the w extraordinarily detailed, skillful drawings, mostly Europ cityscapes, in charcoal or crayon. Clarice stops, at a polite distance from his bars, clears her throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Lecter... My name is Clarice  Starling. May I talk with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Hannibal Lecter is lounging on his bunk, in white paj reading an Italian Vogue. He turns, considers her... A fa so long out of the sun, it seems almost leached - except the glittering eyes, and the wet red mouth. He rises smoo crossing to stand before her; the gracious host. His voic is cultured, soft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: BETWEEN THEM
dialogues.text: as Clarice comes a measured distance closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor, we have a hard problem in  psychological profiling. I want to  ask for your help with a  questionnaire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "We" being the Behavioral Science  Unit, at Quantico. You're one of  Jack Crawford's, I expect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I see your credentials?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice is surprised, but fishes her ID card from her bag holds it up for his inspection. He smiles, soothingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closer, please... Clo-ser...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She complies each time, trying to hide her fear. Dr. Lect nostrils lift, as he gently, like an animal, tests the ai Then he smiles, glancing at her card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) That expires in one week. You're not  real FBI, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm - still in training at the  Academy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack Crawford sent a trainee to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're talking about psychology,  Doctor, not the Bureau. Can you decide  for yourself whether or not I'm  qualified?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmmm... That's rather slippery of  you, Officer Starling. Sit. Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits in the folding metal desk-chair. He waits polite till she's settled, then sits down himself, faces her hap

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now then. What did Miggs say to you? (she is puzzled) "Multiple Miggs," in the next cell.  He hissed at you. What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said - "I can smell your cunt."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. I myself cannot. You use Evyan  skin cream, and sometimes you wear  L'Air du Temps, but not today. You  brought your best bag, though, didn't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's much better than your shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe they'll catch up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no doubt of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shifting uncomfortably) Did you do those drawings, Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. That's the Duomo, seen from the  Belvedere. Do you know Florence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All that detail, just from memory...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Memory, Officer Starling, is what I  have instead of view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause, then Clarice takes the questionnaire from her ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Lecter, if you'd please consider -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no. You were doing fine,  you'd been courteous and receptive  to courtesy, you'd established trust  with the embarrassing truth about  Miggs, and now this ham-handed segue  into your questionnaire. It won't  do. It's stupid and boring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm only asking you to look at this,  Doctor. Either you will or you won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack Crawford must be very busy indeed  if he's recruiting help from the  student body. Busy hunting that new  one, Buffalo Bill... Such a naughty  boy! Did Crawford send you to ask  for my advice on him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I came because we need -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many women has he used, our Bill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five... so far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All flayed...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Partially, yes. But Doctor, that's  an active case, I'm not involved. If -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know why he's called Buffalo  Bill? Tell me. The newspapers won't  say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you if you'll look at this  form. (he considers, then  nods) It started as a bad joke in Kansas  City Homicide. They said... this one  likes to skin his humps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witless and misleading. Why do you  think he takes their skins, Officer  Starling? Thrill me with your wisdom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It excites him. Most serial killers  keep some sort of trophies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You ate yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tense beat, then a smile from him, at this small boldne

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send that through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rolls him the questionnaire, in his sliding food tray He rises, glances at it, turning a page or two disdainful

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Officer Starling... do you think  you can dissect me with this blunt  little tool?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I only hoped that your knowledge -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly he whips the tray back at her, with a metallic C that makes her start. His voice remains a pleasant purr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sooo ambitious, aren't you...?  You know what you look like to me,  with your good bag and your cheap  shoes? You look like a rube. A well- scrubbed, hustling rube with a little,  taste... Good nutrition has given  you some length of bone, but you're  not more than one generation from  poor white trash, are you Officer  Starling...? That accent you're trying  so desperately to shed - pure West  Virginia. What was your father, dear?  Was he a coal miner? Did he stink of  the lamp...? And oh, how quickly the  boys found you! All those tedious,  sticky fumblings, in the back seats  of cars, while you could only dream  of getting out. Getting anywhere - yes? Getting all the way - to the  F...B...I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His every word has struck her like a tiny, precise dart. she squares her jaw and won't give ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see a lot, Dr. Lecter. But are  you strong enough to point that high- powered perception at yourself? How  about it...? Look at yourself and  write down the truth. (she slams the tray  back at him) Or maybe you're afraid to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a tough one, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reasonably so. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you'd hate to think you were  common. My, wouldn't that sting!  Well you're far from common, Officer  Starling. All you have is the fear  of it. (beat) Now please excuse me. Good day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the questionnaire...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A census taker once tried to test  me. I ate his liver with some fava  beans and a nice chianti... Fly back  to school, little Starling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps backwards, then returns to his cot, becoming as  still and remote as a statue. Frustrated, Clarice hesitat then finally shoulders her bag and goes, leaving the  questionnaire in his tray. But after just a few steps, as she passes -

dialogues.speaker: MIGG'S CELL
dialogues.text: She sees that creature at his bars again, hissing at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I b-bit my wrist so I c-can diiiieeee!  S-ee how it bleeeeeeeeds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dark figure suddenly flings his palm towards her, and

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: is spattered on the face and neck - not with blood, but w pale droplets of semen. She gives a little cry, touching fingers to the wetness. Stunned, near tears, she forces  herself to straighten up and walk on, fumbling for a tiss From behind her, Dr. Lecter calls out, very agitated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officer Starling... Officer Starling!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice slows, stops. She shudders, but makes the very  difficult choice to turn, walk back, stand again in front

dialogues.speaker: DR. LECTER
dialogues.text: Who's shivering with rage. For an instant his face opens, and we catch a glimpse into hell itself. Then he's compos again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would not have had that happen to  you. Discourtesy is - unspeakably  ugly to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then please - do this test for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But I will make you happy...  I'll give you a chance for what you  love most, Clarice Starling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that, Dr. Lecter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Advancement, of course. (beat) Go to Split City. See Miss Mofet, an  old patient of mine. M-O-F-E-T...  Now go. Go. (a smile) I don't think Miggs could manage  again so soon, even if he is crazy -  do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grim gothic pile of the asylum looms overhead as Clar rushes out the front doors. She is badly shaken, almost  stumbling, as she rubs at her face. She looks around for, and finally, with some relief, spots -

dialogues.speaker: HER CAR
dialogues.text: an old Pinto, parked nearby. This image begins to BLUR...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: her face, fighting tears, as the CAMERA begins to WHIRL A her, almost dizzily. She is seeing, in her mind's eye -

dialogues.speaker: IN FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: a screen door banging open, on a wooden porch, and a 10-y old girl - the young Clarice - rushing outside, down the  front steps, and running joyfully across her front yard t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a car - late 60's vintage - parked in the dirt road. A MA Clarice's father, is just climbing out. He's tall, handso and has a marshal's badge pinned on his dark suit. He gri seeing her, and spreads his arms wide as...

dialogues.speaker: THE YOUNG CLARICE
dialogues.text: rushes into them, and he sweeps her up in a hug, spinning her around, the CAMERA SPINNING with them, and capturing  both their laughing faces, before we abruptly return to -

dialogues.speaker: THE ADULT CLARICE
dialogues.text: alone in the parking lot, sagging against her car. Her fa is buried in her arms, she shoulders shaking. SOUND UPCUT a steady, rapid series of GUNSHOTS, as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice, in a combat stance, and wearing a sound-muffling headset, is squeezing off ROUND after ROUND at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The silhouette of a man, approaching along a track. Her s tightly grouped, are all finding the center chest. The ta stops, quite close to her, still swaying. Clarice stares at it, deftly working her speedloader. The she puts a final, emphatic shot right through THE FIGURE' FOREHEAD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a microfilm monitor - a grainy newsphoto of Dr.  Lecter, scrawling past, with an accompanying story ("New  Horrors in Cannibal Trial"), dated 1980. Clarice is punching keys on the terminal. Other trainees  study at nearby tables. She pauses, jotting a note on her pad, as Ardelia comes b carrying an armful of books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phone call, Clarice. It's God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Ardelia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Clarice rises, grabbing her notebook, and follows Arde past high metal bookstacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You missed Fourth Amendment law.  Unlawful seizure, real juicy stuff.  Where were you all afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleading with a crazy man, with come  all over my face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ardelia stares at her, figures it's a put-on, laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn. Wish I had time for a social  life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice grins, as Ardelia indicates a phone receiver rest on the check-out desk, then moves on. Clarice picks it up

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) Mr. Crawford?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford, in a cardigan, sits in a wing chair in the book lined study of his suburban home. He turns the pages of  Clarice's memo as they talk. His tone is sharp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've read your interim memo on Lecter.  You sure you've left nothing out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all there, sir, practically  verbatim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every word, Starling? Every gesture?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit heatedly) Right down to the kleenex I used. (he is silent) Sir, why? Is something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He mentioned a name, at the very  end. "Mofet..." Any followup on her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spent all evening on the mainframe.  Lecter altered or destroyed most of  his patient histories, prior to  capture. No record of anyone named  Mofet. But "Split City" sounded like  it might have have something to do  with divorce. I tracked it down in  the library's catalogue of national  yellow pages. (glancing at her notes) It's a mini-storage facility outside  Baltimore, where Lecter had his  practice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pauses, expecting some soft of approval for her  cleverness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well? Why aren't you there right  now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, that's a field job. It's outside  the scope of my assignment. And I've got a test tomorrow on -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you recall my instructions to  you, Starling? What were they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To complete and file my report by  0800 Wednesday. But sir -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then do that, Starling. Do just  exactly that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, what is it? There's something  you're not telling me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Miggs has been murdered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled, upset) Murdered...? How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orderly heard Lecter whispering  to him, all afternoon, and Miggs  crying. They found him at bed check.  He'd swallowed his own tongue...  Chilton is scared stiff the family  will file a civil rights lawsuit,  and he's trying to blame it on you.  I told the little prick your conduct  was flawless. (beat) Starling...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here, sir, I just - I don't know  how to feel about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to feel any way about  it. Lecter did it to amuse himself.  Why not, what can they do? Take away  his books for awhile, and no jello... (a bit softer) I know it got ugly today. But this  is your report, Starling - take it  as far as you can. On your own time,  outside of class. Now carry on.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: as we hear the loud CLICK of Crawford hanging up. She sta at her receiver, stung by his abruptness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well God damn it! You old creep.  Creepo son of a bitch. Let Miggs  squirt you and see how you like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slams her receiver into its cradle.

dialogues.speaker: CRAWFORD
dialogues.text: as he flips aside her memo, then rises, wearily. He leave his study, flicking off the lamp, and pads away in his  slippers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A private nurse, in white, stands marking a clipboard cha as Crawford enters his tidy bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take over, Patricia. You get  some rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nurse nods, hands him the chart, and goes. He glances it, then sets it aside. He crosses to -

dialogues.speaker: BELLA CRAWFORD
dialogues.text: who lies in an elevated hospital bed. Nearby are an oxyge tank and mask, floral arrangements. Her breathing is shal very labored. Crawford looks down at his comatose wife fo long moment, tenderly brushes a strand of her hair back i place, then bends over to kiss her forehead. SOUND UPCUT THUNDER and RAIN...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An orange neon sign, streaked with rain, identifies out  location. It looms over a hurricane fence, topped with ba wire. Inside, row on row of garage-sized, cinderblock she

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unit 31 was leased for ten years.  Pre-paid in full... The contract is  in the name of "Miss Hester Mofet."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice, kneeling before a closed, roll-up metal door, ta a FLASH photo of its sealed padlock. EVERETT YOW, a fat,  60ish Chinaman, holds an umbrella over them both. He look unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So no one's been in here since -  1980?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the padlock, using a fat ring of tagged keys, t sets aside both keys and lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to my knowledge. Privacy is a  great concern to my customers. But,  if you say this is an FBI matter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't disturb anything, Mr. Yow, I  promise. Be gone before you know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slinging her camera over a shoulder, she tugs at the hand but the door won't budge. Another tug, harder - no good. Yow stoops to help, puffing hard, but it's firmly stuck. sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could return tomorrow, with my  son. Or perhaps some workmen...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice crosses to her Pinto, which faces the shed, reach in to turn on her headlights. Mr. Yow blinks in the sudde brightness. Then she opens her truck, rummaging inside, a returns with a bumper jack, a flashlight, and a rubber fl mat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you hold these, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives him her flashlight and camera, drops the mat on the ground, then sets the bumper jack in place, under the center of the door. She pumps on the jack handle as the d SQUEALS slowly up, but it won't go higher than about 18  inches, despite all her exertions. She spreads out the ru mat on the cement, takes the flashlight from Mr. Yow, the lies on the mat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice, backlit, peers under the door. She reaches in, m a sweep with her flashlight. We catch shadowy outlines -  boxes, then the flattened tires of a car... SOUND of rain on the tin roof, and other noises, too - sm RUSTLINGS. Mr. Yow's chubby face appears down beside  Clarice's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It smells like mice... I think I  hear them, too - don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice turns onto her back, starts squirming under the d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice pulls her head back out again, reaching to take h camera from him. She hands him a card, trying to appear  nonchalant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Yow, if this door should fall down -ha ha! - or anything else -  would you be kind enough to call  this number? It's our Baltimore field  office. They know you're here with  me... Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might I suggest tucking your pants  into your socks? To prevent mouse  intrusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice squirms, on her back, through the narrow opening. she squeezes all the way in, she snags one thigh on the m edge of the door. She curses softly, shining her flashlig on her ripped khakis - there's a small streak of blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Miss Starling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Mr. Yow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shines her light around. In its narrow beam, we see -

dialogues.speaker: UPWARD, SHIFTING
dialogues.text: spiderwebs, everywhere... high stacks of cardboard boxes. a few dusty pieces of furniture... the big car, oddly lon and tall, covered with a tarp... Suddenly there's a scurr of loud MUSICAL NOTES. Clarice turns, scared, her beam  capturing... an old upright piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're playing a piano, Miss Starling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wasn't me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice crawls a bit further. There's hardly room to stan but she finally manages to wriggle upright, clawing away  cobwebs, next to the car. Holding her light under one arm she takes several FLASH photos of the shed's interior, en with the car. Then, slinging her camera over the shoulder she folds back the tarp, resting it on the roof. The resu clouds of dust make her cough.

dialogues.speaker: THE CAR
dialogues.text: is an antique beauty, a 1931 Packard. It's very dusty, de the tarp. Curtains close off the back passenger compartme but there's a narrow gap in them. More mousy RUSTLINGS.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: peers in through the gap, aiming her flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: SHIFTING
dialogues.text: as the thin flashlight beam picks out: the broad back sea as open album of lacy, old-fashioned Valentines... a crum lap rug, on the floor... and then a pair of women's shiny high-heeled pumps... Above these, the hem of a fancy sati evening gown - and a pair of pale, stockinged legs. Clarice recoils, alarmed, then steadies herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Yow? Oh Mr. Yow...? It looks  like somebody is sitting in this  car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my! Oh my... Maybe you better  come out now, Miss Starling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet! - just wait for me. (under the breath) Maybe in about two seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leans down with her camera, takes a FLASH through the gap, then tries the door handle. Locked. So is the front  door. She looks around, aiming her light, and locates a t of coat-hangers, sticking out of a carton of bric-a-brac. She pulls out one of these, straightens it quickly, bends the tip into a hook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as she jams this tool inside the join at the top of the b passenger window, then fishes around till she can snag th inside door latch, pulling up. A satisfying CLICK. Clarice opens the door - it hits stacked boxes, and won't open far - then very cautiously leans inside, aiming her  flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: MOVING LIGHT BEAM
dialogues.text: revealing more of the evening gown... a pair of hands, in white, elbow-length gloves - one rests on the lap, the ot atop a large, beaded, drawstring evening bag... thick str of costume pearls over the breasts... and finally the whi neck stub of a female mannequin. No face or head.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: sighs with relief. She takes a couple more FLASHES, then  very carefully lifts out the Valentine album, holding it the corners, and setting it atop the car. Then she eases  herself inside, onto the back seat, as the springs SQUEAK loudly. ONE GLOVED HAND slides off the lap, brushing Clarice's th Clarice starts a bit, then pokes at the gloved arm, hard. She peels back a bit of glove, revealing the white, synth elbow. She smiles, shaking her head at her own jumpiness, she reaches over the mannequin's lap to loosen the evenin bag's drawstring. A SEVERED HUMAN HEAD stares back at her, as the beaded  material slides away. Clarice lurches back, gasping loudly, and several long, h pounding moments pass before she can make herself look mo closely. The head bobs gently in a pool of alcohol, in a laborator specimen jar. It is a man's head, but grotesquely transfo by the addition of heavy makeup, earrings, and a sodden w into a woman's face. Over the years the makeup has smeare badly, and the pupils have gone almost milky white.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: staring at this terrible thing, is pleased to find hersel quickly regaining control. She murmurs to herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Toto, we're not in Kansas  anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A loud clap of THUNDER, as a flash of LIGHTNING illuminat the eerie towers and barred windows of the asylum. MOVING ANGLE on Clarice as she climbs from her car, runs  through heavy rain towards the main entrance, where a gua admits her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a noiseless TV screen, an evangelist rants, waving his arms. Behind him, a swaying choir in gaudy robes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an anagram, isn't it, Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN TO Clarice, with her wet hair plastered flat, sitting the corridor floor to one side of this TV, which has been stationed so that Dr. Lecter cannot avoid seeing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hester Mofet... "The rest of me."  Miss The-Rest-of-Me... Meaning, you  rented that place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he's lost in shadows; we can't see him. He doesn't respon

dialogues.speaker: BETWEEN THEM
dialogues.text: Clarice and the darkened call - as she tries again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You put those - things in there.  Paid for it in advance, ten years  ago... Why, Dr. Lecter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The food carrier suddenly SWISHES out of the cell, making her jump up. In its tray is a clean, folded white towel. hesitates, then crosses, takes this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits again, rubbing her wet hair. When he finally spe he's on the floor, too - a deeper, hunching darkness in t shadows, occasionally striped by the flickering TV light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your bleeding has stopped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did - (she stops herself) It's nothing. A scratch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you ask me about Buffalo  Bill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised, a beat) Why? Do you know something about  him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might if I saw the case file. You  could get that for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you tell me about "Miss  Mofet?" You wanted me to find him.  Or do I have to wait for the lab?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) His real name is Benjamin Raspail. A  former patient of mine, whose romantic  attachments ran to, shall we say,  the exotic...? I didn't kill him,  merely tucked him away. Very much as  I found him, in that ridiculous car,  in his own garage, after he's missed  three appointments. You'd have him  under "Missing Person" - which, in  poor Raspail's case, could hardly be  more true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you didn't kill him, then who  did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who can say...? Best thing for him,  really. His therapy was going nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't it have been easier to just  leave him for the police to find?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And have them clomping about in my  life? Oh dear, no... At that time I  still had certain private amusements  of my own. (beat) How did you feel when you saw him,  Clarice? May I call you Clarice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scared, at first. Then - exhilarated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahhh... Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you weren't wasting my time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have something you use, when  you need to get up your courage?  Memories, tableaux... scenes from  your early life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Next time I'll have to  check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack Crawford is helping your career,  isn't he? Apparently he likes you.  And you like him, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never thought about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your first lie to me, Clarice. How  sad. Tell me - do you think Crawford  wants you, sexually? True, he's much  older, but - do you think he  visualizes... scenarios, exchanges...?  Fucking you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That doesn't interest me, Doctor.  And it's the sort of thing Miggs  would ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not anymore. (beat) Surely the odd confluence of events  hasn't escaped you, Clarice. Crawford  dangles you before me. Then I give  you a bit of help. Do you think it's  because I like to look at you, and  imagine how good you would taste...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or doesn't this all begin to suggest  to you a kind of... negotiation?  There's something Crawford can give  me, and I want to trade for it. I  even wrote to him, offering my help.  But he hates me, so he won't deal  directly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Lecter slowly turns up the rheostat in his cell. As h lights rise, we see that the cell's been stripped bare. G are his books, drawings, mattress - even his toilet seat. She stands, too, startled. They face each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Punishment, you see. For Miggs. Just  like that gospel program. When you  leave, they'll turn the volume way  up. Chilton does enjoy his petty  torments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who killed Raspail, Doctor...? You  know, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been in this room for eight  years, Clarice. I know they will  never, ever let me out while I'm  alive. What I want is a view. I want  a window where I can see a tree, or  even water. I want to be in a federal  institution, away from Chilton - and  I want a view. I'll give good value  for it. Crawford could do that for  me, but he won't. You persuade him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost a whisper) Who killed your patient?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, a very naughty boy. Someone you  and Jack Crawford are most anxious  to meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buffalo Bill...? (incredulous) Bill killed him, all those years  ago...? That's impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Dr. Lecter only smiles, enigmatically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is he stalking right now, Clarice?  I wonder, don't you? How many more  young women will have to die, before  you trade with me...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Clarice stares at him, unsure how to respond -

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: CATHERINE MARTIN takes a long toke from a bong pipe. She 21, a tall, big-boned, rather fleshy girl with long brown fair. Her head is on the lap of her boyfriend, CODY; they sprawled on a couch in the den of her well-furnished  apartment. The TV in on, with low SOUND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This stuff's givin' me the munchies.  Where's that bag of popcorn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. Left the groceries in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to rise, but she pushes him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'S okay, I'll go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rises, goes out the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catherine straightens, with her bag of groceries, shuttin her car's back door. She sees, a short distance away -

dialogues.speaker: A MAN
dialogues.text: standing at the open rear door of a brown panel truck. Hi right forearm is in a cast and sling; he is struggling,  unsuccessfully, to hoist an armchair into the truck. Park nearby, other cars, RVs, a boat on a trailer. A thin, bre high fog fills the lot; arc lights make yellow pools.  Catherine hesitates, then crosses towards the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help you with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you? Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His voice is odd, strained, very soft. A fog lamp, set on end on the ground, distorts his features from below. We c get a good glimpse of his face, but his body is plump, ab average height; he's in his mid 30's. She sets down the b then together they easily lift the chair into the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's slide it up, you mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He climbs inside the truck, ducking under a small hand wi and grabs the chair. She hesitates again, but climbs in a him; together they slide the chair forward, behind the se

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you about a size 14?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, in the shadowy dark, he clubs her over the back her head with his cast. She moans, slumps unconscious, sl off the armchair to lie on her stomach. He pulls off his  cast and sling, tosses them aside, then hops out of the t grabs his lamp, climbs back inside, and pulls the door sh He bends over her face with the lamp. We hear her shallow BREATHING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He peels back the collar of her blouse, reading the size  tag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He carefully slits her blouse up the back, with a pair of bandage scissors, peeling apart the two halves. There's n bra strap. He strokes her bare skin delicately, very happ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gooood...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOW ANGLE - CLOSE - on Catherine's grocery bag, as her bl is tossed out beside it. SOUND of the truck's motor start The truck backs up, one rear wheel knocking over the bag, partly squashing it. Then is drives away, taillights  shrinking, as a lone orange rolls slowly away from the ba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a large video screen, where a BLURRY image gradu sharpens, resolving into two separate pieces of fabric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Electron microscopy reveals fiber  "signatures" that are nearly as  distinct as fingerprints...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice sits at a long table, with other trainees. Ardeli is beside her. Other tables and students in the backgroun Each trainee has his own microscope. Clarice is tired, bu straightens, hearing -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both of these blouses were worn by  victims of Buffalo Bill. They were  found in two different states, and  four months apart. He always slits  them up the back, like a funeral  suit...

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SCREEN
dialogues.text: successively CLOSER VIEWS of the cut fabric edges, until are seeing individual threads, big as tree limbs. The cut match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bunching you see - this  compression - is characteristic of  scissor cuts, rather than a single  blade. And, as you see - Bill always  uses the same pair...

dialogues.speaker: THE DOOR
dialogues.text: as John Brigham, the gunnery instructor, sticks his head

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice Starling! Are you in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice and Brigham walk briskly down the hall, passing o trainees. He carries a small canvas bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your field gear, take stuff for  overnight. You're goin' with Crawford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some fishermen in West Virginia found  an unidentified girl's body. It's a  Buffalo Bill-type situation. Been in  the water about a week, and Jack  needs somebody that can print a  floater. Think you can handle it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinking quickly) I'll need the big fingerprint kit...  and the one-to-one Polaroid, the CU- 5, with film packs and batteries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brigham steers as they pass hangars, parked planes, an  airstrip. Clarice holds a big fingerprint kit and a weeke bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack's pretty tough on you, isn't  he? Impatient...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got a lot on his mind besides  Buffalo Bill... His wife, Bella, is  real sick. Comatose... I'm tellin'  you about it now, 'cause he may never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice absorbs this in silence as they stop near an anci rather dilapidated Beechcraft. Its door is open, the twin props and beacons already turning. Brigham turns to her,  holding out his small canvas bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're goin' in the field, so you  gotta have full kit. Take this -  it's my own...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice opens the bag, stares at the big blue gun nestled its shoulder holster. She looks up at him, touched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wear it, don't ever leave it in your  purse. Dry fire it whenever you get  the chance. And do your exercises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will... I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I hope you never need a thing  I've taught you. But you've got  something... Jack sees it, I do too.  If you ever need to, you can shoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods, climbs out. Then she looks back in at him. They both moved by this rite of passage, but a little embarras

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bless you, Starling...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARICE'S POV - Out the plane's window, at the landscape below. Wisps of cloud, a quilt of farms. Clarice turns from the window, looks at a think folder in her lap. The cover reads "Case File: / BUFFALO BILL." Cla is moody, distracted. She hesitates, then opens the file, begins to scan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police forms, some handwritten... Typed lab reports; we c words, phrases: "Autopsy Protocols", "Histamine Analysis" Grainy enlargements of bullet slugs, showing matched  grooves... And then a stack of victim photos. The first o taken from a good distance away, shows a nude female body face down on a pebbly riverbank, surrounded by bits of li Clarice hesitates again, then flips this photo to look at the next. It makes her flinch, just slightly. Quickly she turns through several more photographs, trying hard to  concentrate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He keeps them alive for three days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: shows Crawford standing over her, swaying with the plane' motion. Behind him, the open cockpit door, the pilot's ba Crawford sits, removing sunglasses. He rubs his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, we don't yet know... There's no  evidence of rape or physical abuse  prior to death. All the mutilation  you see there is post-mortem. (a beat; he glances  at her) I'm hot, are you hot? Bobby, it's  too damned hot back here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pilot adjusts a valve. Crawford turns to her again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. Three days. Then he shoots them, skins them - usually just the torsos -  and dumps them. Each body in a  different river, in a different state,  downstream from an interstate highway.  The water leaves us no fingerprints,  fibers, DNA fluids - no trace evidence  at all. That's Fredrica Bimmel, the  first one...

dialogues.speaker: A COLOR PHOTO
dialogues.text: shows a pretty, plump-cheeked brunette, in her high schoo graduation cap and gown. She smiles at us with touching  optimism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big girl, like all the rest. Went  about 160... Her corpse was the only  one he took the trouble to weight  down, so actually, she was the third  girl found. After her, he got lazy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Clarice stares at the girl's face, moved. Crawford pul a map from the file, spreads it out. It shows the central and eastern U.S., with widely-spaced, hand-drawn markings

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue square for Belvedere, Ohio,  where the Bimmel girl was abducted.  Blue triangle where her body was  found - down here in Missouri. Same  marks for the other four girls, in  different colors. This new one,  today... washed up here. (he marks with a Flair  pen) Elk River, in West Virginia, about  six miles below U.S. 79. Real boonies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no correlation at all between  where they're kidnapped and where  they're found...? (he shakes his head) What if - what if you trace the  heaviest-traffic routes backwards  from the dump sites? Do they converge  at all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good idea, but he thought of it,  too. We've run simulations, using  different vectors and the best dates  we can assign. You put it all in the  computer, and smoke comes out. No,  this one is different. This one has  seen us coming...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford steers, following a highway patrol car along a  winding mountain road. Clarice has the file open on her l He glances at her, inscrutable behind his sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk about him, Starling. Tell me  what you see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (choosing her words  carefully) He's a white male... Serial killers  tend to hunt within their own ethnic  group. And he's not a drifter - he's  got his own house, somewhere. Not an  apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What he does with them - takes  privacy... Time, tools... He's in  his 30's or 40's - he's got real  physical strength, but combined with  an older man's self-control. He's  cautious, precise, never impulsive...  This won't end in suicide, like they  often do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got a real taste for it now.  And he's getting better at his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat; impressed) Maybe you've got a knack for this...  I guess we're about to find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly, evenly) Like I have a "knack" for Dr. Lecter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He studies her a few moments, measuring her anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Starling. Let's have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't said a word today about  that garage. Or what I found there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What should I say? You did fine work.  We'll wait on the lab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You knew. You knew from the start  that Lecter held the key to this...  But you weren't up front with me.  You sent me in to him naked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Are you finished?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts this - buzzing in me, in  my head. He makes me feel violated...  You used me, Mr. Crawford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shadow of regret passes over his face, but he answers  sternly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number One. Maybe there's a  connection, maybe not. Lying and  breathing are the same thing to  Lecter. Number Two. If I'd sent you  in there with something to hide from  him, he'd have known it, instantly.  He'd never have trusted you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to answer, then is silent. He is right. By now the two cars are entering a tidy little town - tre lined streets, wooden houses, one-story shops, mountains the background. They slow, turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number Three, I didn't bring you  along today just because you can do  first-rate forensics. If Lecter is  becoming part of this case, you've  got the most current read on him.  And Number Four - you don't have to  like me, or the way I do things. But  you do have to keep a cool head.  Especially now... Because from here  on out, you'll know everything I do.  Are we straight on that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice nods, silently; it's as close to an apology as sh likely to get. She stares out the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: JUST AHEAD OF THEM
dialogues.text: the highway patrol cruiser noses into a curb, next to oth police cars, facing a big white frame house. Its sign rea "Potter Funeral Home." Two troopers climb from the car. Crawford parks too, then kills the engine. He turns to he removing his sunglasses, gestures to the case file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) You think about him long enough, you  get a feel for him... Then, if you're  lucky, out of all the stuff you know,  one little part of it tugs at you,  tries to get your attention... You  let me know when that happens,  Starling. Live right behind your  eyes, today. Don't try to impose any  patterns on this guy. Just stay open  and let him show you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the troopers, impassive in his sunglasses and hat, peers in through Crawford's window. Crawford nods to him, then turns back to Clarice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: School's out, Starling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUND of organ music, as Clarice, carrying her fingerprin kit, mounts some steps to the sidewalk. She stops, seeing

dialogues.speaker: COUNTRY PEOPLE
dialogues.text: in their somber best, filing into the mortuary for a serv The music - "Shall We Gather At The River?" - is issuing  from the open double doors. Several of the mourners glanc over at her curiously.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: staring back at the mourners, hearing the music, as a sen memory is triggered in her...

dialogues.speaker: IN FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: as we approach, down the aisle of a country chapel, an op wooden coffin. Sad country faces turn, looking at us from the flanking pews. The b.g. organ hymn is "Shall We  Gather...?"

dialogues.speaker: THE SAD, 10 YEAR-OLD CLARICE
dialogues.text: in her best dress, is reluctantly approaching the casket. Her hands are held by the plump hands of unseen matrons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on the looming coffin... closer and closer... until final she can see, lying inside it... her dead father, arms fol his marshal's badge still pinned to his lapel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Starling...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the grownup Clarice turns towards the impatient Crawfo Like her, he carries a large case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're around back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young deputy, several state troopers, and a SHERIFF are all waiting, as Crawford and Clarice enter. The dim, clut corridor doubles as storage space - there's a treadle sew machine, a soft-drink machine, a tricycle. The MUSIC is  closer. Crawford shakes hands with the sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Perkins? Jack Crawford, FBI...  This is Officer Starling. We  appreciate your phoning us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grim, unsociable) I didn't call you. That was somebody  from the state attorney's office...  'For you do a thing else, I'm gon'  find out if this girl's local. It  could just be somethin' that outside  elements has dumped on us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He casts a sidelong, unhappy glance at Clarice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well sir, that's where we can help.  If -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't even know you, Mister... Now  we'll extend you ever courtesy, just soon as we can, but for right now -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff, this, ah - this type of sex  crime has some aspects I'd rather  discuss just between the two of us.  Know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He indicates Clarice with his eyes. The sheriff hesitates nods, then lets Crawford guide him into a small office,  closing the door behind them. Muffled WORDS from there.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: burning at this slight, is left alone with the troopers, peek at her with shy curiosity. She pulls her blazer a bi tighter, self-conscious about her bulging shoulder holste

dialogues.speaker: THE OFFICE DOOR
dialogues.text: as, after a few more moments, the sheriff and Crawford em The sheriff, still not very happy, addresses his deputy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar, run fetch Dr. Akin from the  chapel. And tell Lamar to come on  when he's done playin' that music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford, in one corner of the room, has set up a Litton  Policefax fingerprint transmitter. SOUND of many men's lo voices, in background. He is on the phone, and has to spe loudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a six-way linkup! Chicago,  Detroit, Cleveland, St. Louis,  Atlanta, and Dallas... What?... Can  you hear me...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around, frustrated by the noisy circus atmospher

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: is pulling on a pair of surgical gloves. She raises her v turning up her natural accent by several notches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen. You officers and gentlemen!  Listen here a minute, please. There's  things I need to do for her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as we see that the small room is very crowded with deputi and troopers. They gradually fall silent, looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'all brought her this far, and I  know her folks would thank you if  they could. Now please - go on out  and let me take care of her... Go  on, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men look at one another, a little bashfully, then beg to to file out, whispering among themselves. As they go, bright green body bag is REVEALED, tightly zipped, lying a porcelain embalming table. It is almost the only modern object in this Victorian room, with its glass-paned cabin and faded wallpaper, decorated with cabbage roses.

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING CRAWFORD
dialogues.text: as he looks at Clarice with a new degree of respect. Men  brush by him, till finally only two are left: DR. AKIN, a family g.p., and LAMAR, a lean, whiskey-reddened morticia SOUND of the door closing. Lamar dabs around his nostrils with Vicks VapoRub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) We're starting. Tell everybody to  stand by for fingerprint transmission.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: at a side counter, has turned back to her open fingerprin kit. She is lifting out a camera when she hears the ZIPPE of the body bag being slowly opened, behind her... One gloved hand flies to her mouth as she reacts,  involuntarily, to the sudden smell. She blinks at her  reflection in the cabinet glass, then steels herself to t look at the corpse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause; softly) Bill...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She steadies herself by raising her camera, takes a FLASH photo.

dialogues.speaker: LOOKING UP, FROM BENEATH TABLE
dialogues.text: as Dr. Akin gently lifts aside one of the dead girl's arm A piece of fishing line, with multiple hooks, is still sn around it, dangling. Crawford leans in for a closer look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrongful death... She'll have to go  to the state pathologist at Claxton  when you're done. (Crawford nods) I better - get on back for the rest  of that service. Lamar'll help you. (shaken) Lord almighty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves, and Clarice leans INTO SHOT, taking another ph

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you see, Starling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she's not local. Her ears are  pierced three times each, and she's  wearing green glitter nail polish.  Looks like town to me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on the calf of one of the girl's legs, as Clarice trails inside of her bare wrist along the skin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She waxed her legs, I think... A big  girl, just like the others - but she  was careful about her appearance...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Lamar joins them for a closer look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two of the fingernails are broken  off, and there's - dirt or grit under  the others. She tried to claw her  way through something... I'll scrape  out samples after I've printed her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes another FLASH, then quickly reloads film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Them fishhooks are set too close  together. No wonder the Franklin  boys was scared to say they found  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think they were runnin' a trotline?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford and Lamar both look at her curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Crawford) It's a Fish and Game violation. Like  poaching. There's a big fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right... Are you from around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do it lots of places.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get photos of her teeth. Then we'll  fax her fingerprints to Washington,  try to trace her through Missing  Persons.

dialogues.speaker: CLOSE ON THE DEAD GIRL'S FACE
dialogues.text: staring blue eyes, short reddish hair. Clarice sets the  Polaroid, with its special attachments, against the face, while Lamar gently retracts the lips. Each time the camer FLASHES, there's a bright glow inside the cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: CHEST HIGH
dialogues.text: as Clarice examines a developing print.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's got something in her throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands the print to Crawford; he and Lamar look at it, she searches in her kit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When a body comes out of the water,  alots of times there's like, leaves  and things in the mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice holds up a pair of forceps. She glances at Crawfo who nods. She bends over, partially OUT OF SHOT, and afte few moments reappears, holding up a small, brown cylindri object. She turns this in the air, as they all stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it - some kind of seed pod?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nawsir, that's a bug cocoon. But how  come that to get way down in there?  'Less somebody shoved it in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice and Crawford exchange a glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll be easier to print if we turn  her over. Lamar, will you give me a  hand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir, I will. Clarice takes a jar  from her kit, carefully drops the  cocoon inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUND of the men's heavy efforts as they turn over the bo off screen. She seals the jar, staring into it at the coc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Starling - what do you make of these?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: low on the corpse's back, over the shoulders, two neat,  triangular patches of skin are missing.

dialogues.speaker: TWO SHOT
dialogues.text: as Clarice looks at Crawford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I didn't see those on  any of the other girls...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They weren't there. Get close-ups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice raises her camera, leans in for another FLASH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice sits outside, with her head on her knees, drained She looks up wanly as Lamar appears, offers her a can of  Coke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, I'm not thirsty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, hold it under your chin, there,  and on your temples. Cold'll make  you feel better. It does me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles, touched, and takes the can. When Lamar sees  Crawford coming outside, he tactfully departs. Crawford s beside her; there's a brief silence. She soothes herself  with the can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I told that sheriff we shouldn't  talk in front of a woman, that really  burned you, didn't it? (she is silent) That was just smoke, Starling, I had  to get rid of him. You did well in  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It matters, Mr. Crawford... Other  cops know who you are. They look at  you to see how to act... It matters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Point taken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him a moment, then offers the can. He opens

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we get back, I want you to run  that bug by the Smithsonian, see if  they can identify it. Maybe it's got  some limited range, or it only breeds  at certain times of year... You found  it, Starling, you deserve the credit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm wondering if he's done that before -  placed a cocoon, or an insect. It  would be easy to miss in an autopsy,  especially with a floater... Can we  check back on that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) The other girls are in the ground.  Exhumations are upsetting for the  families. I'll do it if I have to, but -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then have the lab check Raspail's  head. (he looks at her) Dr. Lecter's patient - have them  probe his soft-palette tissues...  They'll find another cocoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem pretty sure of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raspail was killed by the same man  who's killing these girls. And Lecter  knows him. Maybe even treated him...  You think so, too, don't you? Or  you'd never have sent me to that  asylum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her for a moment, then sips again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before we caught him, Lecter had a  big psychiatric practice in Baltimore.  But he traveled all over the country -  teaching, consulting... Christ, even  testifying in murder trials. Who  knows how many potential psychos he  turned loose, just for the fun of  it...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shadowy male figure looks down at us, leaning over the  edge of a deep hole. He holds a little white poodle in hi arms, stroking it. This is MR. GUMB, aka "Buffalo Bill."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Rub the cream on your skin. Rub it  in gooood...

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE MARTIN
dialogues.text: looks up at him. She is standing on the cement bottom of pit, or oubliette, about 15 feet below floor level. The p is bare, except for a futon and a plastic toilet bucket,  from which a thin string rises up to the basement. She's  soaking wet, in an orange jumpsuit, and holds a squeeze b of skin lotion. She struggles to sound calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister... my family will pay cash.  Whatever ransom you're askin' for, they -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rub it in! Or you'll get the hose  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little dog squirms in his arms, BARKING excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it will, Precious, won't it? It  will get the hose!

dialogues.speaker: AT PIT BOTTOM
dialogues.text: as Catherine kneels, turning slightly away from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under her breath) Oh God... oh God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She unzips her jumpsuit, part-way, then squeezes some of lotion onto a palm. She reaches inside her suit, rubs it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister, if you let me go, I won't  press charges, I promise. You've  only had me here a couple days, and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Just one day...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that all...? See - see, my mom is  a real important woman... Well, I  guess you already know that. She'll  pay you, no questions asked. Whatever  cause you represent - Iran, Palestine -  she'll see that -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sudden blinding glare of light silences her. She looks shielding her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a floodlamp is descending, attached to a small basket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put the bottle in the basket. No  funny business, or you'll be sorry...

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: as the basket stops, and she steadies it. But as she slip the bottle in, she sees something, O.S., just at the frin of the light. She hesitates, looks closer... then begins scream, hysterically, again and again. Her outflung hand  hits the lamp, and in its swaying glare, we see - high on the concrete walls, all around her -

dialogues.speaker: BLOODY FINGER TRACKS
dialogues.text: dried now, brownish - left by many pairs of frenzied hand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice is at her desk, exercising her right hand with th grip flexer, while simultaneously studying a thick law bo Ardelia sticks her head in the door, excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better come see this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a TV screen, filled with a photo of Catherine Ma

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...was listed at first simply as a  missing person, but is now believed  to have been kidnapped by the serial  killer known only as "Buffalo Bill."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The photo disappears, replaced by the TV ANCHOR himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Memphis Police sources indicate that  the missing girl's blouse has been  identified, sliced up the back, in  what has become a kind of grim calling  card. Young Catherine Martin, as  we've said, is the only daughter of  U.S. Senator Ruth Martin -

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: looks at Ardelia, surprised. Other trainees are drifting  into the rec room, some whispering among themselves. Clar stares back at the TV intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the Republican junior senator  from Tennessee. And while her  kidnapping is not at this point  considered to be politically  motivated, nevertheless it has stirred  the government -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...to its highest levels, the  president himself being said to be,  and I quote, "intensely concerned."  Just moments ago, Senator Martin  made this dramatic personal plea...

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR MARTIN, (TV FOOTAGE)
dialogues.text: fills the screen, in a halo of lens flare, as she speaks a jostling crowd of reporters on the front steps of her  Georgetown home. A tall woman, late 40's, with a strong,  taut face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
