dialogues.text: I'm speaking now to the person who  is holding my daughter. Her name is  Catherine... You have the power to  let Catherine go, unharmed. She's  very gentle and kind - talk to her  and you'll see. Her name is  Catherine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice is moved by what she sees. Other trainees are all around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Boy, is that smart...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why does she keep repeating the name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody's coaching her... They're  trying to make him see Catherine as  a person - not just an object.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a chance to show the whole  world that you can be merciful, as well as strong. Please - I beg you -  release my Catherine...

dialogues.speaker: NEW FOOTAGE
dialogues.text: as we see (NIGHT, TELEPHOTO) - a taped-off section of  Catherine's parking lot. Technicians, with instruments, a kneeling by the crushed grocery bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile. in Memphis, the  investigation continued throughout  the night, as state and local  authorities were joined at the kidnap  scene by agents of the FBI...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Jack Crawford is seen striding towards the front door Catherine's apartment, followed by Burroughs and other ag One of them moves quickly towards the CAMERA, waving it b

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING ARDELIA
dialogues.text: as the other trainees send up a brief, ironic cheer. But  Ardelia turns sympathetically towards the troubled Claric

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know whether to say "I'm  sorry," or "Congratulations." But  girl? - you just went prime time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The massive Victorian building looms over Constitution Av Clarice quickly mounts the steps, carrying a small plasti box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think he knew that she's a  Senator's child. She's a big girl,  Starling, like all the rest. We're  going on the theory she was randomly  targeted by size...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice, now accompanied by a museum guard, walks through eerie landscape of dinosaur bones - crouching skeletons w blank eye sockets, gaping fangs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now, Bill's had her for 36 hours.  That leaves us just 36 more, before  he kills her... But maybe, just maybe,  Starling, we caught a real break  this time - thanks to you. (beat) We found another bug, in Raspail's  head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON an live, enormous, rhinoceros beetle, as it weav its clumsy way among the men on a chessboard, before fina stepping off the edge, onto a lettuce leaf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time, Pilch! My move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No fair! You lured him with produce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: shows two entomologists, both 30ish, hunched over the boa RODEN is a pudgy redhead; PILCHER is lean, quite handsome

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tough noogies! It's still my turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the beetle moves one of your men,  does that count?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look up, delighted to see Clarice in the doorway. Bo men are hopelessly smitten by her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it counts. How do you play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins) Officer Starling. Welcome back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING ANGLE as Clarice and the two men go briskly down a hall lined with mounted insects, in all shapes and sizes. Roden peers at Clarice's new cocoon, in its box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the hell did this one come  from? It's practically mush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really don't want to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your West Virginia specimen gave us  quite a bit of trouble, but I finally  managed to narrow his species through  chaetaxy - studying the skin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the one who found his perforating  proboscis! Are you wearing a gun,  right now? (Clarice nods) Ooh, cool! Can I see it? Can I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just ignore him. He's not a Ph.D.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VERY CLOSE (MAGNIFICATION) on the sliced cocoon, as Roden uses tweezers and a dental probe to ease out the sodden  chrysalis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole trick is to remove the  chrysalis without destroying it...  The wings are just like wet tissue  paper...

dialogues.speaker: THE TWO MEN
dialogues.text: are hunched over a formica table, peering through square  magnifiers into stainless trays. Clarice watches curiousl Of their two specimens, Pilcher's moth is in much better  condition - a big brown creature, its wings outspread on  towel paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking up) What do you do when you're not  detecting, Officer Starling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I try to be a student, Dr. Pilcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever get out for cheeseburgers and  beer? The amusing house wine...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Not lately. But maybe someday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up at her, shyly. A little moment passes between them, before Roden straightens, exultant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Positive match!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points with his dental  probe) West Virginia... Baltimore. Officer  Starling, meet Mister Acherontia  Styx.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves aside for Clarice to get a closer look at Pilche specimen. She leans forward, intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the wide, furry, brown back of the moth. And there, right between the wing bases - wonderful and terrible to see - nature's perfect reproduction of a ghostly human skull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better known to his friends as the  Death's-head Moth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Latin name comes from two rivers  in Hell. Your man - he drops these  girls into rivers, every time. Didn't  I read that?

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING CLARICE
dialogues.text: as she looks up at him, awed, excited, almost trembling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there's no way - no natural way -  these could've wound up in the bodies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) They live in Malaysia. In this  country, they'd have to be specially  raised, from imported eggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause, then softly) Dr. Lecter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the two men stare at her, puzzled, we hear a SOUND UPC the wail of police SIRENS - and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An awesome armada of police vehicles swings through an  intersection, while normal traffic is held back by highwa patrol cruisers. The lead cars turn off, hit the entrance ramp to the free SIRENS going, tires SQUEALING, red flashers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on a speeding surveillance van, with long antennas and a  small satellite dish, near the head of the motorcade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we can trace how he buys the  bugs, starting with U.S. Customs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The van is crammed with an impressive array of hi-tech  equipment, all CLICKING and HUMMING. Burroughs is talking quietly on a scrambler phone, while another agent works a computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we can locate some of Raspail's  old lovers. Maybe, someday...

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE AND CRAWFORD
dialogues.text: sit in swivel seats at the rear, by a big window. Clarice can't resit an occasional peak at the trailing motorcade, awed and a bit thrilled to be the center of so much atten

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But for Catherine Martin, it all  comes down to you and Lecter. You're  the one he talks to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's already offered to help... What  would happen if we just showed our  cards - asked him for Bill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He offered to help, Starling, not to  snitch. That wouldn't give him enough  chance to show off. Remember, Lecter  looks mainly for fun. Never forget  fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if he knew we have so little  time -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we act too anxious, he'll make us  wait. He'll let the Senator keep  hoping, day after day, until Catherine  finally washes up. That'd be the  most fun of all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he means it, this time. I  think he'll deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would it take?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Transfer to a new prison. With a  view of trees, he said, or even  water... Can we swing that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) State to federal jurisdiction... We  can do it - eventually - but we'll  never get all the clearances in time.  Can you convince him a deal's already  in place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll back me up with some paperwork? (he nods) Then I'll try. But wouldn't this  have more weight coming from the  Senator herself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitates) She doesn't know what we're up to.  And we can't afford to let her find  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice looks at him, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's the mother, Starling. She can't  possibly comprehend what Lecter is.  She'd make the mistake of pleading  with him. Begging him... He'd feast  on her pain till the last second of  that girl's life...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chilton approaches, walking briskly down a corridor in th administration wing. He looks quite agitated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't trust Frederick Chilton,  either. He's greedy and ambitious.  If he knew about Lecter's link to  Bill, he's go straight to the  newspapers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chilton falls into step beside Clarice, who has her brief He points his gold pen at her accusingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you're doing, Miss Starling, is  coming into my hospital to conduct  an interview, and refusing to share  information with me. For the third  time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Chilton, I told you - this is  just routine follow-up on the Raspail  case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's my patient! I have rights! (grabs her arm,  stopping her) I'm not just some turnkey, Miss  Starling. I shouldn't even be here  this afternoon. I had a ticket to  Holiday on Ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares at him, with pity and distaste, till he lets g

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm acting on instruction, Dr.  Chilton. (handing him a card) This is the U.S. Attorney's number.  Now please - either discuss this  with him, or let me do my job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks away, leaving him speechless with frustration a hostility. He clicks his pen, watching her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Lecter sits at his table, languidly sketching with  charcoal on butcher paper. He uses his own hand and forearm as a model. His other  drawings, books, and bedding have been restored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you say, Clarice, that for  a United States Senator, you're an  odd choice of messenger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice, sitting again at the desk-chair, is taking paper from her briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was your choice, Dr. Lecter. You  chose to speak to me. Would you prefer  someone else now? Or perhaps you  don't think you can help us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is both impudent and untrue...  Tell me, how did you feel when you  viewed our Billy's latest effort? (beat; he smiles) Or should I say, his "next-to-latest"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the book, he's a sadist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life's too slippery for books,  Clarice. Typhoid and swans came from  the same God. (beat) Tell me, Miss West Virginia - was  she a large girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big through the hips. Roomy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm. And what else...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She had an insect deliberately  inserted in her throat. That hasn't  been made public yet. We don't know  what is means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it a butterfly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause; staring at  him) A moth... How did you predict that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm waiting for your offer, Clarice.  Enchant me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice looks down at her papers, taking a moment to coll her thoughts. She looks up at him again, evenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you help us find Buffalo Bill in  time to save Catherine Martin, the  Senator promises you a transfer to  the V.A. hospital at Oneida Park,  New York, with a view of the woods  nearby. Maximum security still  applies, but you'd have reasonable  access to books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is silent. She rises, moves closer, carrying papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best of all, though - one week a  year you'd get to leave the hospital  and go here. (points to a map) Plum Island. Every afternoon of that  week you can walk on the beach or  swim in the ocean for up to one hour.  Under SWAT team surveillance, of  course...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face remains neutral. She puts the papers in his food tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Copy of the Buffalo Bill case file,  copy of Senator Martin's terms. Her  offer is final and non-negotiable.  If Catherine dies - (she slides his tray  through) You get nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A measured beat, before he rises smoothly, crosses, and l down at the papers, without touching them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Plum Island Animal Disease Research  Center." Sounds charming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just part of the island. It  has a very nice beach. Terns nest  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terns... If I help you, Clarice, it  will be "turns" with us, too. Quid  pro quo. I tell you things, you tell  me things. Not about this case, though -  about yourself. Yes or no? (she is silent) Yes or no, Clarice. Catherine is  waiting. Tick-tock, tick-tock...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him. A beat. They are standing uncomfortably close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your worst memory of childhood? (she hesitates) Quicker than that. I'm not interested  in your worst invention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The death of my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me. Don't lie, or I'll know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice cannot bear the feverish excitement in his eyes. looks past him, hesitating again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a town marshal... one night  he surprised two burglars, coming  out the back of a drugstore... They  shot him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killed outright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. He was strong, he lasted almost  a month. My mother - died when I was very young, so my father had become -  the whole world to me... After he  left me, I had nobody. I was ten  years old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're very frank, Clarice. I think -  it would be quite something to know  you in private life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quid pro quo, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The significance of the moth is  change. Caterpillar into cocoon into  beauty... Billy wants to change,  too, Clarice. But there's the problem  of his size, you see. Even if he  were a woman, he'd have to be a big  one...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Dr. Lecter, there's no correlation  in the literature between  transsexualism and violence.  Transsexuals are very passive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clever girl. You're so close to the  way you're going to catch him - do  you realize that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Tell me why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After your father's death, you were  orphaned. What happened next? (Clarice drops her  gaze) I don't imagine the answer's on those  second-rate shoes, Clarice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went to live with my mother's cousin  and her husband in Montana. They had  a ranch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cattle ranch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horses - and sheep...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long did you live there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why so briefly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I - ran away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, Clarice? Did the rancher fuck  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he try to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...! Quid pro quo, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy's not a real transsexual, but  he thinks he is. He tries to be.  He's tried to be a lot of things, I  expect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said - I was very close to the  way we'd catch him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are three major centers for  transsexual surgery: Johns Hopkins,  the University of Minnesota, and  Columbus Medical center. I wouldn't  be surprised if Billy has applied  for sex reassignment at one or all  of them, and been rejected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On what basis would they reject him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The personality inventories would  trip him up. Rorschach, Wechsler,  House-Tree-Person... He wouldn't  test like a real transsexual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would he test?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Dr. Lecter snarls, loudly, stretching. Clarice t a sharp step backwards before he smiles, turning his move into an elaborate yawn. He gathers the papers from his tr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough, I think. Happy hunting.  Oh, and Clarice - next time you will  tell me why you ran away. Shall I  summarize?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaken) Yes, Doctor. Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VERY CLOSE ON a cocoon, split along its back, as a living Death's-head Moth wriggles torturously free. Trembling an damp, the new creature clings to a sprig of nightshade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should try to obtain a list of  males rejected from all three gender  reassignment centers...

dialogues.speaker: PULLING BACK
dialogues.text: we see a big wire cage, holding several of the moths. The crawl over the humus floor or feed at honeycombs, wings  pumping lazily. In the distant background, the incongruou SOUND of show music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check first the ones rejected for  lying about criminal records...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at about knee level, as we leave the cage, and begin to T through this eerie, dimly-lit warren of a cellar. As we go - occasionally TURNING corners, or skirting the  dark openings of unexplored passages - various objects lo briefly INTO VIEW, overhead - a stainless-steel work tabl a big sink... jars of chemicals... neat racks of gleaming knives...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Among those who tried to conceal  their past, look for severe childhood  disturbances, associated with  violence... Possibly you'll find a  childhood incarceration... Then go  to their personality tests...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pass a row of female mannequins, some nude, some weari colorful leather jackets, designer knockoffs, in various  stages of completion... then a huge maroon armoire, in Ch lacquer; its double doors are slightly ajar... The jaunty background. MUSIC is growing even louder: Fats Waller singing "Bye By Baby." And now we hear something else, too - the rapid  CLICKING of a sewing machine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Study their drawings, especially.  Billy's house drawings will show no  happy future... No baby carriage,  out in the yard. No pets, no toys,  no flowers, no sun...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We TURN another corner, and there is Mr. Gumb himself. As APPROACH, his wide back is to us; he's hunched over an ol fashioned sewing machine, humming cheerfully, and working piece of material that we mercifully cannot see. A female wig rests near him on a head form. He wears a hairnet and beautiful kimono, and pumps the treadle with his bare fee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His females will be more crudely  sketched than him males - but he'll  compensate by adding exaggerated  adornments... jewelry, big breasts...  And his tree drawings - oh, his trees  will be frightful...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next to Mr. Gumb is an antique phonograph - source of the MUSIC. His little dog, Precious, perches by his plump ank As we PASS Mr. Gumb, Precious scurries away from him, pan happily, and we FOLLOW the little dog down another corrid the music starting to fade behind us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy hates his own identity, he  always has - and he thinks that makes  him a transsexual. But his pathology  is a thousand times more savage...  He wants to be reborn, Clarice. He  will be reborn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the end of this final corridor, the cellar widens into low-ceilinged chamber, with two additional doorways, and the center of this is the gaping circle of the oubliette. Precious sniffs her way over to the edge - excited, tail  wagging - than BARKS happily as we hear a hoarse, ghostly moan from below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleeeeeeeease.....!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING ANGLE - CLOSE ON Dr. Lecter's slippered feet, whic rest on the shelf of a rolling hand truck. RISING along h tilted form, we see that his ankles are linked by steel  restraints... his legs, waist, upper torso, and arms are  bound by heavy canvas webbing... beneath the webbing is a strait-jacket... and over his face is a hockey mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad news, Hannibal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: shows that Dr. Lecter, on the handtruck, is being pushed  down his corridor by Barney, and back into his open cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gourmet magazine has rejected your  recipe for braised kidneys...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chilton lounges on Dr. Lecter's cot, casually reading his large stack of private correspondence, and making notatio with his gold pen on a little pad. Another orderly mops t floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you should have been less  specific about what kind. (to Barney) Stand him by the toilet. Then leave  us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney props the hand truck into position, then both orde go. Chilton finishes another letter, sighs happily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such a lot of correspondence! I can  hardly wait to analyze it in more  detail... But first things first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tossing letters onto the cot, he rises, crosses out into corridor, and bends to remove a small tape recorder from  underneath Clarice's desk. He waggles it triumphantly at Lecter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought she might be looking for a  civil rights violation in Migg's  death, so I bugged you... Not a word  to me in all these years, Hannibal.  Then Crawford sends his bit of fluff  over here, and you just turn to jelly.  It's too pathetic.

dialogues.speaker: TWO SHOT
dialogues.text: as Chilton, back in the cell, leans tauntingly close to t front of Dr. Lecter's mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still think you're going to walk  on some beach, and see the birdies?  I don't think so, Hannibal... I called  Senator Ruth Martin, and she never  heard of any deal with you. She never  heard of Clarice Starling, either.  They scammed you, Hannibal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON Dr. Lecter's glittering eyes, behind their slits

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Crawford gets through milking  you, he's giving you to Baltimore  Homicide for the Raspail murder. And  they're preparing some special  surprises for you right now, in my  electroshock room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: first looking at Chilton's moving lips... then LOWERING t his soft, white, inviting throat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Starling bitch wants you to rot  here, in this little box, till your  teeth fall out and you're soiling  diapers. You've seen the old ones,  Hannibal. They weep when their stewed  peaches get cold. That'll be you,  too. Unless - you trade with me.

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING CHILTON
dialogues.text: as he sits chummily on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There never was a deal with Senator  Martin - but there is now. I've been  on the phone for hours, Hannibal, on  your behalf. Here's what you get: if  you identify Buffalo Bill, and the  girl is found in time, Senator Martin  will have you transferred to Brushy  Mountain State Prison, in Tennessee...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as they shift restlessly, away from Chilton - then sudden lock onto something. They widen with interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Governor has already agreed. You  get books, a view of the woods, and  plenty of exercise time...

dialogues.speaker: EXTREME CLOSEUP
dialogues.text: On the cot, carelessly left there, lying half-hidden unde the letters and the rumpled sheet... is Chilton's gold pe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And best of all, you'd be out of  Jack Crawford's reach, forever. The  Senator will verify these terms on  the phone, and guarantee them in  writing...

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON DR. LECTER
dialogues.text: as he stares a moment longer at the pen, then shifts his  eyes towards Chilton. We can almost hear his brain clicki

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In exchange, I get your full  cooperation in publishing a  professional account of this - my  successful interviews with you. You  publish nothing. And I get exclusive  access to any material from Catherine  Martin... So. Do you accept my  demands? (pause) Answer me, Hannibal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Dr. Lecter is silent. Chilton sticks his face INT SHOT, almost intimately close to the mask. He is agitated

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll answer me now, or by God,  you'll answer to Baltimore Homicide.  Who is Buffalo Bill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause; then softly) I'll tell the Senator herself. But  only in Tennessee...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING ANGLE - as the very impatient Crawford, clutching folder, strides down a hall beside DR. DANIELSON - early  50's, severe, in a lab coat. Nurses, doctors, glance as t pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not having a witch hunt here,  Mr. Crawford! Our patients are decent,  non-violent people with a real  problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Danielson, the man we want was  never your patient. It would be  someone you refused because he tries  to conceal a record of criminal  violence. Please, Doctor - time is  eating us up. Just show me the ones  you've turned away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danielson enters a cramped, stainless steel nurse's galle with Crawford following, and pours himself a cup of coffe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (adamantly) Examination and interview materials  are confidential. We've never violated  an applicant's trust, and we never  will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to see a violation? This is  a violation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a black & white photo from his folder, slaps down in front of Danielson. From our angle, we can't see clearly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her name is Kimberly Jane Emberg,  she was just ID'd. I met her on a  slab in West Virginia. And sometime  tomorrow, or tomorrow night, he's  going to do the same thing to  Catherine Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a childish, bullying stunt,  Mr. Crawford. I was a battlefield  surgeon, so you can put away your  picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burroughs sticks his head in, looking for Crawford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phone, Jack. Director Burke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snaps) In a minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burroughs hurriedly retreats. Crawford strains for patien

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look... search your own records, if  you prefer. You can do it a lot faster  than us, anyway. If we find Buffalo  Bill through your information, I'll  suppress it. Nobody has to know this  hospital cooperated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt very much that the FBI or  any other government agency can keep  a secret, Mr. Crawford. Truth will  out... And then what? Will you give  Johns Hopkins a new identity? Put a  big pair of sunglasses on this  building, and a funny nose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's clever, Dr. Danielson.  Very humorous. You like the truth?  Try this. (right in his face,  enraged) He kidnaps young women and kills  them and rips their skin off. We  don't want him to do that anymore.  If you don't help me, just as fast  as you can, then the Justice  Department is going to ask publicly  for a court order, We'll ask twice a  day, just in time for the morning  and evening news. And each one of  our press conferences will focus on  Dr. Danielson, over at Johns Hopkins,  and how we're still hoping for his  cooperation. And every time there's  any news on the case - when Catherine  Martin floats, when the next one  floats, and the next one - why, we'll  just issue another press release  about good ol' Dr. Danielson, over  at Johns Hopkins - complete with all  his humorous fucking remarks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause; stiffly) It may be that - I could confer with  my colleagues on this. And get back  to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you, Doctor? That would be so  kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford is on the scrambler phone. Burroughs watches  silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone; stunned) Transferred...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAYDEN BURKE, the FBI Director, swivels in his big chair. Lean, late 40's, very distinguished. His desk is flanked flags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) Already airborne for Memphis. Senator  Martin's meeting him at the airport. (uneasily) Jack - did you make some sort of  promise to Lecter, in the Senator's  name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listening to the answer, he looks uncomfortably across hi desk at PAUL KRENDLER, the Deputy Attorney General - 40,  very tanned, modish haircut. Krendler is irritable, impat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) We're going to have to talk about  this, Jack. The Senator's mad as  hell. Paul Krendler's over here from  Justice, she's asking him to take  charge in Memphis... I know that...  But you're still in command of the  task force, and Lecter's plane can  still be ordered back. It's your  call, Jack - but I want it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burroughs starts to make an objection, but Crawford still him with a hand motion. He is taut, frustrated. Long paus

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Let him land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice opens her door, stares out at Crawford. She's jus slipping on her blazer, over her shoulder holster. She's  furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chilton has killed her, hasn't he?  That slimy little bastard! We were  so close with Lecter - and now her  last chance is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get some coffee and talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING ANGLE on Clarice and Crawford, as they walk along sidewalk, sipping from paper cups. The surveillance van t them slowly, radios CRACKLING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you in trouble over this, Mr.  Crawford? Can Senator Martin do  something to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm 53, Starling. If I found Jimmy  Hoffa on national TV, I'd still have  to retire in two years. It's not a  consideration. But you are... (beat) You've done enough. If I keep you  out of school any longer, you'll be  recycled. Cost you six months, at  least. I can guarantee you readmission  here, but that's about it. (he stops, looks at  her) Now's your chance, Starling. Go back  to class. Leave Bill to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you didn't want me chasing him,  you shouldn't have taken me to that  funeral home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her steadily, then nods. They walk on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lecter is still the key, I know he  is. Whatever he told me about Bill  is just as good now as it was before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or just as worthless. But I want you  in Memphis, close to him. Maybe when  he gets tired of toying with Senator  Martin, he'll talk to you again.  There's a plane waiting for you now  at the airstrip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles at this acknowledgment; he never thought she's quit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lied to Lecter. I'll need some  kind of peace offering... Can I get  the drawings from his cell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good idea. Meantime, try to get a  feel for Catherine Martin. Her  apartment, her friends... how he  might've stalked her. I'm going to  the other two clinics, Minnesota and  Ohio. (he crumples his cup,  tosses it) Now's the hardest part, Starling.  Use your anger, don't let it keep  you from thinking. Just keep your  eyes on Catherine. We've got less  than 30 hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Mr. Crawford... can those cops down  there handle Dr. Lecter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly) They'll use their best men. But they  better be paying attention...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON Dr. Lecter. Behind his mask, the alert, searchin eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He will...

dialogues.speaker: OFFICERS PEMBRY AND BOYLE
dialogues.text: two sturdy, well-armed, veteran prison guards - are check Dr. Lecter's restraints with clever, careful fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to Memphis, Dr. Lecter. I'm  Officer Boyle, this is Officer Pembry.  We aim to treat you just as nice as  you treat us. Act like a gentlemen,  you'll get three hots and a cot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we ain't pussy-footin' with you,  buddy ruff. You get cute, try to  bite somebody? - we'll tie your  asshole in a knot. You savvy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, Officer Pembry. I certainly  do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The officers turn away, Boyle signing a clipboarded form.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Shit, he's just an ol' broke-dick.  Won't be no trouble as all if he  don't flip out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Chilton...?

dialogues.speaker: WIDER
dialogues.text: as we see that we're in a vast, dusty hangar. Parked to o side: an EMS ambulance and four highway patrol cruisers; dozen troopers stand quietly chatting and smoking over th Prentiss is pacing impatiently, casting anxious glances  towards the open hanger doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'll please sign right here,  sir, we'll have us a legal transfer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chilton instinctively pats his shirt pocket for his gold  pen; it's gone. He searches other pockets, with growing  unhappiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Use mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here they come.

dialogues.speaker: TWO BLACK STRETCH LIMOUSINES
dialogues.text: glide smoothly into the hangar, stop. Secret Service agen pour out of the lead car, form a cordon. A driver opens t rear door of the second car, and Krendler steps out, foll by the Senator's assistant, with a briefcase, followed, a last, by the Senator herself. Barely glancing around, she strides towards Lecter.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LECTER AND SEN. MARTIN
dialogues.text: as she stops, struck by the bizarre spectacle of his  restraints. The others instinctively keep a distance, but Chilton, with theatrical relish, unstraps and removes Dr. Lecter's mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senator Martin, meet Dr. Hannibal  Lecter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stare at one another for a long moment: the Senator  tense, almost haggard, the madman with his unearthly pois

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Lecter, I've brought an affidavit  guaranteeing your new rights... You'll  want to read it before I sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He assistant unsnaps his briefcase, reaches for the form.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't waste your time and  Catherine's time bargaining for petty  privileges. Clarice Starling and  that awful Jack Crawford have wasted  far too much already. I only pray  they haven't doomed the poor girl...  Let me help you now, and I'll trust  you when it's all over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have my word. Paul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Krendler raises a pad, poised to take notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buffalo Bill's real name is William  Rubin. I met him just once. He was  referred to me in April or May, 1980,  by my patient Benjamin Raspail. They  were lovers, but Raspail had become  very frightened. Apparently Rubin  had murdered a transient, and - done  things with the skin. He thought if  I could cure Billy, then Billy'd be  safe from the police, and he's be  safe from Billy... Obviously, he was  wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need his address, a physical descr-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you nurse Catherine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause; startled) What...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you breast-feed her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He flicks his tongue obscenely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You son-of-a -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Senator stills him with a hand. She is trembling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toughened your nipples, didn't it...? (a beat; then rapidly,  bored) Six foot one, strongly built, about  190 pounds. Hair brown, eyes pale  blue. He'd be about 35 now. He said  he lived in Philadelphia, but may  have lied. That's really all I can  remember, Senator - but if I think  of any more, I'll let you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the others) Let's go with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start towards the car, but he calls out, stopping he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senator Martin...! You can't trust  Jack Crawford or Clarice Starling.  It's such a game with these people.  They're determined to get the arrest  for themselves. The "collar," I think  they say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Doctor. I'll keep it in  mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, and Senator...? Love you suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON scraps of food - peas, chicken bones - lying on cement floor of the pit, near the foil tray of a TV dinne

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering, feisty) Close enough to fuck is close enough  to fight...

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: is hunched over in concentration. The plastic toilet buck is on her lap, and she has yanked down its cotton string.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get my legs round your neck, you  goddamn creep, I'll send you home to  Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: HER FINGERS
dialogues.text: are tying a chicken bone to the bucket's handle, where it meets the string. The other end of the string is tied to wrist.

dialogues.speaker: SHE STANDS
dialogues.text: gathers the coiled string in one hand, and swings the buc by its handle, calculating this distance up to the baseme floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Precious. Time for a treat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hurls the bucket upwards.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE LIP OF THE OUBLIETTE
dialogues.text: the bucket sails out, bounces LOUDLY, then falls back ins

dialogues.speaker: THE DOG, PRECIOUS
dialogues.text: who is elsewhere in the basement, worrying a toy. She coc an ear, making a low GROWL, then sets off to investigate.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN IN THE PIT
dialogues.text: Catherine swings the bucket again, trying another cast.

dialogues.speaker: THE BUCKET LANDS
dialogues.text: two feet beyond the pit's edge, rolls a bit, stops.

dialogues.speaker: PRECIOUS TROTS UP
dialogues.text: then pauses, staring curiously towards...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the enticing chicken bone, six feet away. It twitches as  Catherine tugs on the string, edging the bucket back towa the pit. Precious with her tail wagging, BARKS - greedy but suspic

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: staring upwards, pulls again, even so gently, at the stri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Preeeeecious...! C'mon, boy, nice  yummy bone... c'mon, you little  shit...

dialogues.speaker: PRECIOUS
dialogues.text: edges reluctantly closer... then suddenly rushes in, seiz the bone in her teeth. She tries to run away with it, but Catherine is pulling her towards the hole, working her li a hooked fish. Her toenails scrabble as she tries to stop

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: stares desperately, unable to see how she's doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on, boy... hang on...

dialogues.speaker: PRECIOUS
dialogues.text: still fights for the bone, GROWLING, as the bucket rocks  precariously on the edge of the pit. A long, seesaw battl until finally, when one of her forelegs slips momentarily into the hole, she panics and lets go. The bucket flops o the edge.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: crouches, covering her head as the bucket bounces off her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nooooo...!

dialogues.speaker: THE LITTLE DOG
dialogues.text: furious, BARKS down at her, then trots away in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: as she sinks to the cold cement. She slaps aside the foil tray, the scraps of food, sobbing in utter despair...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a framed photo of Sen. Martin and Catherine, hel in Clarice's cotton-gloved hands. Powdered fingerprints o the glass. Clarice glances up from the photo, smiles disarmingly at A young STATE TROOPER sitting in Catherine's easy chair. smiles back at her, then relaxes, returns to his newspape He also wears gloves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice closes the refrigerator door, glances around. A big REEL-TO-REEL TAPE RECORDER has been set up on the  breakfast counter, attached to Catherine's phone. Two new red phones are hooked up as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice slides open the medicine cabinet's mirror, looks  inside. She reaches in, pokes carefully amongst the lotio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ceiling hatch bangs open, sending up dust clouds. Clari lit from underneath, pokes her head through, looking arou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flat on her back, Clarice wriggles out from under Catheri bed. She sits up, brushing dust from her face and hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON an open, multi-tiered jewelry box, resting atop bureau, as Clarice's fingers pick through costume jewelry Clarice closes the box, and is just turning away when a f suddenly looms INTO SHOT, giving her a bad start; she cri out softly. Senator Martin is revealed, staring at her suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you, please? I thought the  police were through in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Clarice Starling, Senator. FBI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly, very angry) Clarice Starling... (calls out) Paul? Would you come in here,  please...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Krendler enters from the hallway, looks at Clarice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Starling, you may know the Deputy  Attorney General, Mr. Krendler. Paul,  this is the trainee that Jack Crawford  sent to Lecter... She lied to him,  pretending to have my authority, and  thus jeopardized this entire  investigation. Now she has the further  gall to invade my daughter's privacy,  again without permission. If her  little games have killed my baby...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overcome, she hurries from the room. Krendler shuts the d behind her, points sternly at Clarice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're out of line, Starling, and  you're off this case. Back to  Quantico.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, Mr. Crawford instructed me -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your instructions are what I'm giving  you now. Jack Crawford answers to  the Director, and the Director answers  to me. My God, Crawford's losing  it...! He shouldn't even be on this,  with his wife sick as she is... How  the hell did you get in here, anyway?  He gave you - what? Some kind of  special ID? Let's have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stubbornly) I need the ID to fly with my gun.  The gun belongs in Quantico.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gun. Jesus. Turn in the ID as soon  as you get back. The gun, too. Be on  the next plane, Starling, there's  one in 90 minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice, burning, starts for the door, then turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Krendler... Dr. Lecter trusts  me. Or at least, he used to. If I  could just -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lecter has already named Buffalo  Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice reacts, surprised. Krendler takes a folded comput sheet from his pocket, shoves it at her. She takes it, re

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gave us a perfectly good  description, and we're on it now, so  we won't be needing your little  novelty act any longer - or his,  either. He's under close guard at  the courthouse, pending a prison  transfer. The next plane, Officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, doesn't this "William Rubin"  strike you as - I don't know - kind  of vague?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Krendler moves in very close to her, pale with anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you need a police escort, Starling?  Or do you think you can find the  airport by yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir. I can find it by myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old courthouse is a massive Gothic stronghold, with a armada of police cruisers parked at the curb. Clarice climbs from her rented car, SLAMMING the door ang Holding a rolled-up pile of papers - Dr. Lecter's drawing she starts determinedly up the steps. A nearby commotion  makes her pause. Dr. Frederick Chilton in a sea of interviewers and mini-c is preening grandly.  Clarice carefully avoiding his gaze, slips up the steps a inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SGT. TATE, a Memphis policeman, is studying Clarice's ID. looks up at her from his command desk, a bit doubtfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you with Mr. Krendler's people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just left him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Access to Lecter is strictly limited.  We've been getting death threats. (hesitates again) Log in, and check your weapon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up a phone, murmurs into it. As he does so, Clar glances around this main ground floor lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The building looks like an armed fort. Cops with shotguns guard the front door, both ends of the hall, the foot of stairs, the single elevator. More of them are coming and  going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot, we haven't had this kinda  security since the President came  through town...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice and OFFICER MURRAY, a young patrolman, ride up in old-fashioned, CREAKING, metal-cage elevator. He is excit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every cop in Tennessee wants a look  at this guy. 'Sit true what they're  sayin' - he's some kinda vampire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) I don't have a name for what he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pembry, at a desk by the door, looks up from examining th unrolled pile of Dr. Lecter's drawings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the rules, ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Officer Pembry. I've questioned  him before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waves her on her way, but retains the drawings for now

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as she crosses the big, spare, white octagonal room. A  massive, temporary iron cage has been installed; Officer  Boyle sits facing its barred door. He rises, nods, moving away to allow her privacy.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE CAGE
dialogues.text: a cot and a small table, each bolted to the floor, and a  flimsy paper screen, hiding a toilet. Dr. Lecter sits at table, his back to her, studying the Buffalo Bill case fi He now wears a green prison jumpsuit. A small cassette pl is chained to the steel table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without turning) Good afternoon, Clarice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops at a striped police barricade, before his bars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you might want your drawings  back... Just until you get your view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How very thoughtful... Or did Crawford send you here for one last wheedle -  before you're both booted off the  case?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody sent me. I came on my own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He spins in his swivel chair, stops neatly. A coy smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People will say we're in love. (beat) Pity you tried to fool me, isn't it?  Pity for poor Catherine. Tick-tock...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He spins again in his chair, playfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as she circles the cage, trying to keep his face in sight

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Lecter, you find out everything.  You couldn't have talked with this  "William Rubin", even once, and come  out knowing so little about him...  You made him up, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice... you're hardly in a position  to accuse me of lying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you were telling me the truth  in Baltimore - or starting to. Tell  me the rest now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've studied the case file, have  you...? Everything you need to find  him is right in these pages. Whatever  his name is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then tell me how.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First principles, Clarice. Simplicity.  Read Marcus Aurelius. Of each  particular thing, ask: What is it,  in itself, what is its nature...?  What does he do, this man you seek?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kills w-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply, as he stops) No! That's incidental.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ANGLE - TWO SHOT as he rises, pained by her ignoran and crosses to the bars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is the first and principal thing  he does, what need does he serve by  killing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anger, social resentment, sexual  frus-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he covets. That's his nature.  And how do we begin to covet, Clarice?  Do we seek out things to covet? Make  an effort to answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. We just -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Precisely. We begin by coveting  what we see every day. Don't you  feel eyes moving over your body,  Clarice? I hardly see how you  couldn't. And don't your eyes move  over the things you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, then tell me how -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's your turn to tell me,  Clarice. You don't have any more  vacations to sell, on Anthrax Island.  Why did you run away from that ranch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Lecter, when there's time I'll -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't reckon time the same way,  Clarice. This is all the time you'll  ever have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, listen, I'll -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll listen now. After your father's  murder, you were orphaned. You were  ten years old. You went to live with  cousins, on a sheep and horse ranch  in Montana. And - ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And - one morning I just - ran away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns from him. He presses closer, gripping the bars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not "just," Clarice. What set you  off? You started what time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early. Still dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then something woke you. What? Did  you dream...? What was it?

dialogues.speaker: IN FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: The 10-year old Clarice sits up abruptly in her bed,  frightened. She is in a Montana ranch house; it almost da Strange, fearful shadows on her ceiling and walls... a wi partly fogged by the cold; eerie brightness outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard a strange sound...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was it?

dialogues.speaker: THE CHILD RISES
dialogues.text: crosses to the window in her nightgown, rubs the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know. I went to look...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shadowy men, ranch hands, are moving in and out of a near barn, carrying mysterious bundles. The mens' breath is  steaming... A refrigerated truck idles nearby, its engine adding more steam. A strange, almost surrealistic scene..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screaming! Some kind of - screaming.  Like a child's voice...

dialogues.speaker: THE LITTLE GIRL
dialogues.text: is terrified; she covers her ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got dressed without turning on the  light. I went downstairs... outside...

dialogues.speaker: THE LITTLE GIRL
dialogues.text: in her winter coat, slips noiselessly towards the open ba door. She ducks into the shadows to avoid a ranch hand, w passes her with a squirming bundle of some kind. He goes  into the barn, and she edges after him reluctantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I crept up to the barn... I was so  scared to look inside - but I had  to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the open doorway LOOMS CLOSER... Bright lights inside, straw bales, the edges of stalls, then moving figures...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what did you see, Clarice?

dialogues.speaker: A SQUIRMING LAMB
dialogues.text: is held down on a table by two ranch hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambs. The lambs were screaming...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A third cowboy stretches out the lamb's neck, raises a bl knife. Just as he's about to slice its throat -

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE ADULT CLARICE
dialogues.text: staring into the distance, shaken, still trembling from t child's shock. We see Dr. Lecter, over her shoulder, stud her intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were slaughtering the spring  lambs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...! They were screaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you ran away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. First I tried to free them... I  opened the gate of their pen - but  they wouldn't run. They just stood  there, confused. They wouldn't run...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you could. You did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took one lamb. And I ran away, as  fast as I could...

dialogues.speaker: IN FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: a vast Montana plain, and crossing this, a tiny figure - little Clarice, holding a lamb in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where were you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I had no food or water.  It was very cold. I thought - if I  can even save just one... but he got  so heavy. So heavy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tiny figure stops, and after a few moments sinks to t ground, hunched over in dispair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't get more than a few miles  before the sheriff's car found me.  The rancher was so angry he sent me  to live at the Lutheran orphanage in  Bozeman. I never saw the ranch  again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what became of your lamb? (no response) Clarice...?

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: as the adult Clarice turns, staring into his feverish eye She shakes her head, unwilling - or unable - to say more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still wake up sometimes, don't  you? Wake up in the dark, with the  lambs screaming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think if you saved Catherine,  you could make them stop...? Do you  think, if Catherine lives, you won't  wake up in the dark, ever again, to  the screaming of the lambs? Do you...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! I don't know...! I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a pause; then, oddly  at peace) Thank you, Clarice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a whisper) Tell me his name, Dr. Lecter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Chilton... I believe you know  each other?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Clarice turns, startled, and the fuming Chilton seizes her elbow. Pembry and Boyle are beside him, looking grim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out. Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, ma'a m - we've got orders to  have you put on a place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice struggles, pulling free of them for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brave Clarice. Will you let me know  if ever the lambs stop screaming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving closer to the  bars) Yes. I'll tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise...? (she nods. He smiles) Then why not take your case file? I  won't be needing it anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out the file, arm extended between the bars. She hesitates, then reaches to take it.

dialogues.speaker: SLOW MOTION
dialogues.text: as the exchange is made, his index finger touches her han and lingers there, just for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LECTER'S EYES
dialogues.text: widen, crackling at this touch, like sparks in a cave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good-bye, Clarice.

dialogues.speaker: CLARICE
dialogues.text: hugging the case file to her chest, stares back at him as the men crowd in on her, pushing her away.

dialogues.speaker: MOVING
dialogues.text: as Dr. Lecter, head cocked in a smile, slowly recedes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING ANGLE - MR. GUMB'S POV as he pushes a rolling rack completed leather garments, each wrapped in plastic, down aisle. SOUND of many sewing machines, all clattering at o as he passes row on row of work tables. The seamstresses, mostly black or Hispanic, glance up as he passes, then qu avert their eyes, his presence disturbing them in some  nameless way. A thin FOREMAN in a flowery shirt, sees him approaching. rises from his desk and comes over cheerfully, as the rac rolls to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, dear! Punctual as always. And  what have you brought us today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seizes one of the dangling jackets, pulling up the pla wrapper. He examines it, stroking the sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, marvelous... You know, I always  say you're the Leonardo of leather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a harsh whisper) Oil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're leaving oil on the skin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The foreman quickly releases the jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course... You'll be wanting your -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gumb's hand reaches INTO SHOT, snatching an envelope  from him. The foreman is watching him walk away, as a  seamstress comes over to take the rack of garments. The  foreman is vaguely troubled, but shakes it off. He stroke the jacket again, admiringly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to seamstress) I wish we had a dozen like him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUND UPCUT - Glenn Gould playing Bach's Goldberg  Variations...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarice, in a line of other passengers, is moving slowly  towards a departure ramp. Through a huge plate glass wind we can see her plane. She glances back over her shoulder A pair of UNIFORMED COPS brawny and impassive, their arms folded, waiting to make sure she board the flight. Clarice sighs, turning wearily back towards the jetway. T BACH CONTINUES, as we...

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a steaming, rather elegant dinner tray, being ca by Pembry, as he approaches Dr. Lecter's cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts) Ready when you are, Doc!

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CELL
dialogues.text: the BACH is issuing from the cassette player. Beside it, the table, the pile of Dr. Lecter's drawings. The top one an accurate, sensitive portrait, from memory, of Clarice. Beyond the table, we see Lecter's shadowy form, seated be the paper screen. He calls out from there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just another minute, please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pembry grunts, sets the tray down. Boyle joins him, handi him a riot baton and a Mace cannister, which Pembry faste to belt clips. Boyle is similarly armed, and carries a ri of keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sumbitch demanded lamb chops for  dinner, extra rare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) What you reckon he'll want for  breakfast - some fuckin' thing from  the zoo?

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE SCREEN
dialogues.text: Dr. Lecter sits fully clothed on the toilet - swaying  slightly, eyes closed, lost in the music, tongue working his cheek. Suddenly, like magic, a little shiny piece of  metal protrudes from his lips. He plucks it out, opens hi eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he is holding the pocket clip from Prentice's disassemble pen - a straight, thin strip of metal, with a circular co at one end, a square edge at the other.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LECTER
dialogues.text: lines up his thumbnail just shy of the square edge, then  braces it against the stainless steel toilet rim. He push down, hard, using both hands for leverage. After a moment smiles, holding up the result, and twirling it before his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the straight end of the clip now forms a tiny right angle and the circular end anchors nicely between his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE CELL
dialogues.text: Pembry and Boyle turn as the toilet FLUSHES, and Dr. Lect reappears, looking jaunty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Doc, grab some floor. Same  drill as lunchtime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Lecter sits on the floor, legs straight, then wriggle backwards. He stretches his arms behind him, hands and wr through the bars, with two bars between them, and clasps hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm ready when you are, Officer  Pembry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pembry comes around the cell to squat behind Dr. Lecter. tugs his hands farther out, rather roughly, handcuffs his wrists. He shakes the cuffs, making sure of them, then no to Boyle.

dialogues.speaker: AT CELL DOOR
dialogues.text: as Boyle picks up the dinner tray, and Pembry crosses aro Pembry takes the keys from Boyle, unlocks the cell door, pushes it inward. Boyle goes inside with the tray.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LECTER
dialogues.text: watches as Boyle approaches the table, above five feet fr him. Boyle has to set his tray down on the floor to clear off some of the mess of drawings. The MUSIC plays on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Dr. Lecter's hands, outside the bars, as the makeshift key, held between the tips of his right index and middle  fingers, searches for the keyhole of the cuffs. And finds it.

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING BOYLE
dialogues.text: as he finishes clearing the drawings, then turns back tow Dr. Lecter, stooping to pick up the tray.

dialogues.speaker: BOYLE'S RIGHT HAND
dialogues.text: is just inches from the tray when Dr. Lecter's hand darts INTO SHOT, snapping a handcuff onto his wrist.

dialogues.speaker: BOYLE
dialogues.text: looks up, astonished, to find himself right in the grinni face of Dr. Lecter - who just as quickly rolls sideways, snaps -

dialogues.speaker: THE OTHER CUFF
dialogues.text: around the bolted leg of the table. And suddenly all natu SOUND and MOTION are suspended, as the MUSIC soars much  louder, each separate note of it now echoing distinctly, we see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pembry starting into the cell, reaching for his riot bato Dr. Lecter smashing against the cell door, driving it int Pembry, pinning him across the chest, against the door  frame... Boyle, on one knee on the floor, digging desperately in h pants pocket for his handcuff key... Pembry's hand, mashed against his body by the door, as he strains frantically to reach the baton at his waist...  Pembry's eyes, widening in horror as he stares at... Dr. Lecter's bared teeth, flashing towards him... Dr. Lecter gripping Pembry's face in his jaws, shaking it like a dog shakes a rat... Boyle finding his key, but in his terror dropping it... Dr. Lecter yanking the mace can and riot baton from the d Pembry's belt, spraying him in his bloody face, then club him to his knees... Boyle, mouth open in a silent scream, finding his key aga unlocking the handcuff, but then, as he starts to rise,  seeing... Dr. Lecter standing over him, with the riot baton raised  high; he swings it viciously down, again and again and  again... Then normal SOUND and MOTION are restored as we go to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the cassette player, and the portrait of Clarice, both no flecked with blood. In addition to the Bach, we now hear  soft PANTING, close by, and whimpering SOBS in the backgr

dialogues.speaker: DR. LECTER
dialogues.text: eyes closed, lost in a favorite passage of the music. His bloody fingers drift airily with the notes, as his breath slows to normal. He opens his eyes, sighs contentedly, lo down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the sprawled legs of Boyle lie various objects that sp from his pants pocket - coins, a comb, a big pocketknife.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LECTER
dialogues.text: picks up the pocketknife, examines it happily. About a fo inch blade. He becomes aware of the WHIMPERING, off scree turns.

dialogues.speaker: PEMBRY
dialogues.text: as he crawls, with torturous slowness, towards the comman desk, and the phone. He is crying, but frantically determ

dialogues.speaker: PARTIALLY BLURRED, THEN CLEARING
dialogues.text: Above the desk, hanging from pegs, are his and Boyle's  holstered revolvers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bronze arrow above the elevator swings towards "5," t indicates a stop there, at the top floor.

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING SGT. TATE
dialogues.text: at his command desk, as he stares at the indicator. Anoth cop, JACOBS, sits on the desk's edge, flipping through a  magazine; many more cops can be seen beyond them, idling the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this shit...? Did somebody  go up to five? (Jacobs shakes his  head) Call Pembry, ask him what -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GUNSHOT, and then, moments later, TWO MORE quick ones,  echo down the nearby stairwell. Sgt. Tate jumps to his fe grabs a radio mike, as the other cops stir, confused and  noisy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into mike) CP, shots fired on five! Repeat,  shots fires on five! Outside posts  look sharp, we've got a... Ho-ly  shit.

dialogues.speaker: THE BRONZE ARROW
dialogues.text: has begun to descend. Down to 4, then past 4...

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON SGT. TATE
dialogues.text: as he reacts. The other cops, behind him, are now in a fu uproar, shouting, pulling out guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the others) SHUT UP...! Guard mount, double up  on your outside posts. Bobby, get  the vests. Rainey, Howard, cover  that fucking elevator if it comes  all the way to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It stopped!

dialogues.speaker: THE BRONZE ARROW
dialogues.text: has, indeed, frozen at 3. Sgt. Tate lifts the microphone  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into mike) Seal off a ten-block radius. Get me  the SWAT team and an ambulance, double  quick. We're going up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HIGH ANGLE on Sgt. Tate as he leads a five-man squad, all bulletproof vests, up the stone stairs. They move fast bu carefully, covering each other from landing to landing wi drawn revolvers, shotguns. The distant Back MUSIC makes a ghostly echo in here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thin rectangle of light on the floor from the open elev door. We can't see inside. The MUSIC sounds closer.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. TATE
dialogues.text: approaches very cautiously, gun aimed. The other cops, be him, fan out silently to set up angles of fire, checking various office doors - all locked - as they creep up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he reaches the side of the elevator, hesitates, then s to point his gun inside. It's empty. He backs away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts at ceiling) Pembry? Boyle...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE on the door, from inside, its lettering reversed on the frosted glass. The Bach is VERY LOUD. After a moment the door is shouldered open, hard enough f the glass to shatter, Tate following his gun inside, movi low, then other cops appearing behind him in the doorfram They all freeze, staring in utter horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no... no...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is a brief snapshot from hell. The two uniformed bodies, sprawled on its back near the door, the other still in th cell, have been savaged by a knife. Blood and gore everyw The faces are unrecognizable.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. TATE
dialogues.text: struggles for control, as the other cops move grimly arou him, into the room. He pulls his walkie-talkie from his b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into mike) Command post... Two offi- (a beat; clears his  throat) Two officers down. Prisoner is  missing. Repeat, Lecter is missing...  He's stripped the bed, might be making  a rope, check all windows. Where the  fuck is my ambulance?

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CELL
dialogues.text: a cop angrily punches OFF the music. Jacobs kneels with h fingers on Boyle's neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boyle is dead, Sarge. His gun's  gone...

dialogues.speaker: AT THE OTHER BODY
dialogues.text: a cop gently removes a revolver from the bloody fist. Mur the young patrolman, brings his ear reluctantly close to gory face. A bloody bubble appears there; the wreckage GR very softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one's alive!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tate crosses, kneels to see for himself. Murray looks gre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take ahold of him where he can feel  your hands, son. Talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's his name, Sarge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Pembry, now talk to him, God  dammit. (into radio, looking  around) Boyle's dead, Pembry's read bad.  Lecter is missing and armed - he  took Boyle's gun...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other cop, checking the cylinder of Pembry's gun, hol up one finger to Tate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into radio) Pembry got off one round - there's a  chance Lecter was hit. We heard a  total of three shots fired, so he's  got four left... He's got a knife,  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VARIOUS ANGLES on a floodlit scene of barely controlled  pandemonium. Flashing red lights, men shouting commands,  SIRENS in the distance. SWAT members, in full gear, leap  from a black van... fan out... swarm up the steps... EMS  orderlies unload a gurney from an ambulance... Cops kneel for cover behind cars, aiming guns and rifles up at the  windows...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A trio of EMS orderlies work fast over the body, already  strapped on its gurney. They bandage a big plastic airway into place, over the butchered face, checking for a pulse the neck. Young Murray crouches, sickened, gripping a blo fist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're just fine, Pembry, lookin'  good, buddy, you're gonna make it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One orderly massages the heart. Another is popping a plas bag, ready to insert the needle, when the body starts  convulsing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Downstairs - let's go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quickly the gurney is elevated, wheeled out of the room,  with cops rushing forward to open the doors, help push, S men are running by in the hall, automatic rifles at the  ready...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sgt. Tate, riding down with Jacobs, has his radio out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into mike) Ten-four, Lieutenant. I'm on the  elevator, bringing it down. Pembry  and Boyle are both cleared, top three  floors secured, main stairwell  secured. He's somewhere on -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A spot of blood falls on his cheek. He and Jacobs stare a each other. Another spot hits his shoulder. They look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blood is dripping slowly from the corner of the service h Sgt. Tate motions for silence, as both men draw their gun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into mike) Uh, we're pretty sure he's somewhere  on two, sir... That's all for now,  over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator doors open, and Tate and Jacobs hurry out,  stepping quickly to the side. Tate reaches back in and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Locks the elevator into position, with its doors open. OTHER COPS are rushing up to them, curious, as Tate  frantically pushes them aside, gesturing for silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) He's on the roof of the elevator!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two SWAT officers, PETERSON and KUBELL, turn a key, unloc and opening this floor's elevator doorway. The shaft is d Lying prone, they inch up to the edge, Peterson extends a mirror, on a long pole, out into the shaft.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MIRROR, (DISTORTED BY THE ANGLE)
dialogues.text: Is a distant figure, in a green prison jumpsuit, lying on his stomach, atop the elevator. A shiny revolver is near hand.

dialogues.speaker: PETERSON
dialogues.text: whispers into a radio, as Kubell carefully tips an assaul rifle, with a flashlight taped to its barrel, over the ed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see him... There's a weapon by his  hand. He's not moving...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you get the drop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got the drop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One warning. Then take him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peterson nods to Kubell, who switches ON the flashlight, Peterson shouts down the shaft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quinn!! put your hands on your head!!

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MIRROR
dialogues.text: the green figure shows no movement.

dialogues.speaker: THE COPS AGAIN
dialogues.text: as Peterson mutters to Kubell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put one in his leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
